16016976.review:
First, probably important for you to know, I read the [b]unvoiced 1st season[/b]. 

So lets start: It's a non-optional visual novel, in other words, just mashing your mouse button / return key and reading is all you'll find in this game, paired with some sounds and pictures, suiting the story, and a soundtrack, supporting the actual mood of the story. The soundtrack contains - at least, as I guess, after playing for almost 3 hours - probably only two songs, but I didn't recognized this as a problem, yet it worked out really well, since you got to know whether that scene was sad or just glumly just by recognizing the right song. The sound effects also were fine, even if I got somehow scared, hearing - the first sound of a human, not a car or the waves - a girl crying and sobbing. 
Coming next to the pictures, I'm somehow unimpressed. I got the impression, that there are too less pictures. Plus pictures barely showed humans, making it very unlively. Also more than a few pictures were used too often. The effect, the soundtrack, containing only a few songs, had, reaches here for the opposite. It formerly tells you "yes, in the car again, nothing new, nothing exciting at all" and you may come to think it's really boring, not worth going on with reading. That somehow got to be my case, but there are also a few other points according to that.
The text itself is written from a to the protagonist limited narrator, containing very much dialogs. 
[i] And here comes the reason why I wrote "unvoiced" in bold in the first line:[/i]
It's unbelievable hard to follow who is saying what. When it was almost over, you could tell from the way the characters speak, who just said that, but in the beginning, it's a real pain and it confuses and makes the story incredibly boring.
Honestly, I was close to quitting the game mid-way. 
Well, I continued till the end, always thinking "no matter how sad it is going to be, since I was so confused in the first part, I won't be affected that badly (meaning I won't show any emotion like setsumi)". But I have to say, I was at least a bit wrong. It didn't got me that hard, but it [i]was[/i] somehow sad.

[spoiler] There is another problem, I had with the story: WHY THE HELL IS THE PROTAGONIST A GUY??! Either I missed that part, in the first few sentences or it was supposed to be like that. But now, I have a different view on everything what happened. It confuses me even incredibly more. I somehow dislike the protagonist being a guy, I would prefer that story, I already imagined all the time, dealing with two girls. [/spoiler]

If you wanna give it a try, being interested in this visual novel, please, for your own sake, play the voiced version.
I started the second season just yet, this time voiced, and until now, nobody except the protagonist - [i]a girl[/i] - was dubbed. I have no idea, if that's the same case in the first season, I won't try. I also won't go on reading the second season, because I don't think it's worth anymore, confusion being the cause.

I hope I did help you, deciding whether you should give this novel a try, since it's for free.

15977991.review:
[h1]Overview:[/h1]
This is a visual novel where there will be images associated with words. It's just like kindergarten story time~! The story however takes on a bit more grim setting than your usual happy endings.

[h1]The Story:[/h1]
       You were like any other child until you were diagnosed with a terminal illness at five years of age. In & out of hospitals since getting sick you've lost contact with your childhood friends and disassociated yourself from life as an complacent observer living life day by day. After the hospital has done everything they can for you they send you to a floor away from the daily bustle of other coming & going patients. Going to the morbid, but supposedly happy recreational room on the floor you meet another patient. You're informed of the rule of the floor by another terminal patient of how you will die and how you must inform others of the rule when they arrive just like you. Dissatisfied of how you will die without experiencing life you finally decide to runaway taking your fellow patient with you, but unfortunately harsh reality sets in as your friend eventually succumbs to...

[h1]2nd Narcissu:[/h1]
  I can only imagine it's among the same setting as the 1st whereas there will be a pair of friends and a ******. Might be wrong, so find out for yourself.

I will leave the rest for you to discover if you're interested.

[h1][b][u]Achievement Hunters: [/u]
[spoiler]
Press Ctrl to skip through story.

1st Narcissu:
Prologue + 8 Chapters
2nd Narcissu:
Prologue + 19 Chapters

It will take you approximately 30min[Not Skipping] to finish each storyline once then all you have to do to unlock the unvoiced achievement is to run through the last chapter.

The hidden achievement is the Epilogue in the start menu. Not sure if voiced, or unvoiced matters.
[/spoiler]

15976798.review: Read the first one, not eager for the second. Painful story of death and suicide, and how we allow immovable realities to dictate our lives, and how we might change them a little by doing ridiculous, risky things. It's not an ineffective novel, but it is a bleak one. I don't come away from this book feeling I know much more than I came into it with, nor will I remember the characters. Nevertheless, it was poignant throughout, and well written. I would say that the author is talented and smart, but this book itself is a well illustrated process of slowly dying while grasping at the last few straws of life, and that is what reading it feels like. I simply can't recommend the experience.

15879690.review:
This horrible, horrible visual novel made be cry! As its intention was evoking emotions, it did the job.

Let's get down to business (I will keep this spoiler-free). Narcissu visual novels (VN) are not strictly games: they have no interactive parts whatsoever. You can just click away and the story continues linearly with no choices. Even the achievements are just reading the novels to their ends.

Narcissu (both of them) is a story about people [i]living with[/i] a terminal disease. Note the emphasis. It's a highly emotional and tragic story, with death being a constant theme. Nevertheless, the characters lives are what's important.

Curiously, the type of the disease is left unrevealed in all cases, emphasising the life of the person instead of the sickness. At all times the story follows one of the protagonists from their perspective, revealing what goes through their head. (Most) Protagonists and some important characters have voice-overs for their dialogue. Scenes are covered by nice, melodical piano songs and occasional other instruments.

Apart from many other visual novels, the visuals are very simple: usually there's just a serene scene that depicts the place where the events take place e.g. a kitchen or a countryside. There are very few scenes with people. The style didn't appeal to me strongly. However, I think that at important (i.e. dramatic) times the scenes were well done.

A couple of things about 1st and 2nd novels separately. In my opinion Narcissu 1st begins slowly, with the protagonist being admitted to a hospital and angsting away there. In Chapter 1 it seems like nothing is happening and frankly I was bored while reading it. Fortunately, in half-way through Chapter 2 it finally begins happening, so be sure to endure until that time. Narcissu 2nd is better in this respect as it has a branching story line from the beginning with several characters.

While both VNs are originally Japanese, there are fortunately two English translations of Narcissu 1st. The Agilis translation (the one I read thoroughly) has rather lot of typos and in some small parts it is left unfinished. To me it felt rather clunky. Only afterwards I briefly checked the gp32 translation and it turns out gp32 is a more polished and "proper" translation to English than Agilis. Narcissu 2nd has only Agilis translation to English that was fortunately a lot better and more polished than the one in Narcissu 1st.

For me, Narcissu 1st was 3-hour read and 2nd a 5-hour one. While it's possible to skip through the story by pressing CTRL for achievements, I can recommend reading through the story: it's an emotional and even revealing experience to issues and thoughts of people suffering from difficult diseases. As such, it provokes one to think about life perhaps from a new perspective. To me, that makes it worthwhile a read.

15846878.review:
公開当時は大いに話題になった、日本製同人ノベルゲーム「ナルキッソス」の1・2抱き合わせバージョン。
シナリオ・音楽・声優全てプロによる作品なのになんと無料。

【Narcissu 1st】
ある病院の7階－ホスピス－に入院することになった主人公は、そこで全てにおいて無関心な少女・セツミと出会う。
ある日、偶然のチャンスを利用し父親の車を盗み出した主人公は、
7階でも家でも死にたくないというセツミを連れ、病院を飛び出す。
一号線をひたすらに西へ、水仙が咲き誇るという淡路島を目指して・・・

【Narcissu SIDE 2nd】
1stよりもさらに昔のお話。
まだ病状が比較的軽く通院しているセツミと、7階の住人・姫子の交流を描いた物語。


時系列的は2→1だけど、普通に公開順に1→2とプレイしたほうがいいかと。
後付だとは思うけど1におけるセツミの行動原理や、車や地理に異常に詳しかった理由も2をやればその背景が見えてくる。

個人的には2の方がかなり心を抉られた。
7階住人、つまり「去る者」のみが話の中心だった1と違い、
2はセツミを始め、姫子の妹・千尋や親友・優花、
そして[spoiler]かつてヘルパーだった姫子[/spoiler]といった、「残される者」の心理描写が濃密に描かれている。
大切な人が死にゆく時、「弱っていく姿を傍で見ていたい」か「知らぬ間にいつの間にか亡くなって欲しい」か、
逆に自分が死にゆく立場だった場合、大切な人に「最期まで傍にいて欲しい」と思うか、
それとも「自分のことなど忘れて欲しい、自分のせいで悲しまないで欲しい」と思うか。
そういった究極の選択を、様々なキャラの立場から、真っ向から描いていく。

このゲームはいわゆる「泣きゲー」ではないと思う。
あからさまに泣かせようとする描写はないし、ただ淡々と、会話が繰り広げられていくだけ。
しかしプレイ後には心に大きなインパクトを残していく、そんな作品。

This visual novel is definitely worth giving a try if you like to read a beautiful but sad story. Unlike most visual novels this one doesn't have the characters speak to you, and appear in the picture, it usually merely shows a picture of the current location the characters are at, but despite that it's more enough to let you visualize, probably because the story itself is good enough to pull you in. And also the music is really good. It fits the moods and settings perfectly.

I've played visual novels I had to actually pay for before that were disappointing both story wise and lenght wise. This one is free, and is at least around 4 hours worth of reading and the story is actually really good. Emotional, yes. But in a beautiful and inspiring way. I wouldn't have minded to have to actually have paid for this visual novel, it delivers a lot more than some you have to pay for do.

15829912.review:
It has no choices. It has no puzzles. It has nothing but a deep and heart touching story line about the meaning of life (and death) and those precious moments in between. What would you do if you knew you were dying, confined to a hospice floor? This is the general premise of the story, though there is much more to it than that. Thought provoking, with tender and human moments, this novel brought tears to my eyes more than once and at the end it was a story i was glad to have heard (read). 

My one and only dis on this would be the graphics. Don't get me wrong, they were nice, but they were lacking a bit. I feel they could have put more into the "visual" aspect of this novel. For example: the empty cars and grey screens. I get that it left more to the imagination, but it came off as a tad lacking in effort in my personal opinion. Still, for a free offering, this novel is wonderful and would have been worth paying a little for. 

Great rainy day read. 8/10

15824949.review:
Best visual novel I read in years. It doesn't rely on visuals and there is no erotism but lot's of emotions, relies on it's writing style and soundtracks. There is a heavy use of piano in the soundtracks which adds more emotion to the story. We can clearly see that the writer didn't want it to be a tear-jerker, it made me cry, made me smile and at some place it made me think about my own life and my regrets.
   I recommend the voiced reading with auto-play since Setsumi's voice acting is really great. Though I can't say the same for Himeko. Her voice acting, also written in the Narcissu 2nd side notes, is faulty in some places but if you can overlook it, it's pretty much great, too. I also advice you to read all the notes after finishing the story.

15819494.review:
Narcissu 1st & 2nd war meine erste Visual Novela. Zuerst sei gesagt: Es handelt sich hierbei nicht wirklich um ein Game sondern eher um eine Art Buch/Manga welches mit Musik, tollen Bildern und einer Sprachausgabe erweitert wurde. Wer nun ein Spiel erwartet sollte weiter suchen. Wer Spaß am lesen hat und auch vor einem zugegeben harten Thema nicht zurück schreckt sollte sich dieses Bundle nicht entgehen lassen. Die Story ist wundervoll geschrieben und ich hätte niemals gedacht das ich bei so etwas wirklich damit kämpfen müsste nicht in Tränen auszubrechen. Neben der japanischen Synchro gibt es eine englische. In der Patchsektion ist mittlerweile auch eine deutsche Übersetzung zu finden - ich empfehle aber weiterhin die englische da einiges mit der Übersetzung ins deutsche "merkwürdig" formuliert wird und ein wenig unpassend wirkt. Nichts desto trotz kann ich dieses "Meisterwerk" wirklich nur empfehlen. Es hat alles was eine gute Geschichte braucht und es macht nachdenklich. Auch für den Einstieg in das Genre ist es eine tolle Gelegenheit zumal diese Novel free 2 play ist. Auch der Soundtrack lohnt sich! Viel Spaß beim erleben und mitleiden!

Story:   10/10
Musik:  10/10
Bilder:    8/10

15753114.review:
J'ai été littéralement transporté dans ce jeu, me tenant au coté de ces deux personnages, différent l'un et l'autre : l'un est une fille de 22 ans, pas bavarde et rêveuse, l'autre un garçon de 21 ans, plus social. Mais un point commun les réunient : Ils vont tous les deux mourir. Ne suportant ni l'hôpital, ni leurs propres maisons, ils décident de s'enfuirent et de trouver un endroit où la fille veut mourir.
Nos deux protagonistes vont parcourir plus de 900km à travers le Japon, alternant des moments heureux, de paix et des moments de confusion, de larmes et de détresse.
L'ost est vraiment puissante et colle bien aux différentes situations (OST dispo pour 7 euros) 
Bien que le jeu soit en anglais, il est très compréhensible si on a un niveau correct et est gratuit.Non, je ne devrais pas parlé de jeu mais d'histoire textuelle (light novel sans choix), un petit roman pleins de sentiments qui vous fera réfléchir et vous fera voir et comprendre ce que ceux qui sont comdamné à mourir dans quelques semaines ressentent.
Si une traduction en francais voit le jour, je me ferai un plaisir de le refaire pour assimillé toutes les suptilités de cette aventure.
Je vous le recommande vivement.

15700131.review:
Right off the bat I must warn you that as a media, Narcissu is essentially a picture book. You'll do a lot of reading accompied by the occasional illustration; if that sounds boring to you, walk away... but give the soundtrack a listen at least. With that out of the way, we can continue.

This is a story about death and dying, and how people react to and cope with it. It revolves around three protagonists, each condemned to die of their illnesses, as they spend the remainder of their times outside of the normal hierachy of society. Each will break out of the sterile enviroment of the hospice that contains them to travel in search in what their lives - and their deaths - truly means to them.

If that has you rolling your eyes, I cannot fault you; death is an exceedingly common topic and terminal illnesses have been all but done to... death. Narcissus in particular suffers somewhat from putting excess focus on how cold and sterile just about everything and everyone around the protagonists are. However, if you can pardon the occassional melodrama, you will find that the rest of the story are wonderfully thought-provoking, and that there are brutal truths regarding society's treatment of the dying contained within.

I would be remiss not to mention the soundtrack, which is definitely an integral part of the experience. The music is a perfect fit for the story that it accompanies, and I am certain that you will find at least a couple of tracks in there that will stick with you for a very long time; my personal favourite would be Narcissu 2nd's opening vocal.

All in all, I heartily recommend that you at least give Narcissu a try. To paraphrase the author's notes: regardless of what you think of it, I hope that at least it made you think.

15673967.review:
POSSIBLE SPOILER WARNING! I tried to avoid them as much as possible.          The game is self is split in to two parts, the first and second side. I made the mistake of playing them in the oposite order so that might affect my general rating of it. If you come into it expecting gameplay you will get none, are no choices to be made of enviroments to explore. Its entirely on rails. However as someone who just got into Visual Novels this didn't really bug me. The real meat, or should I say only meat is in the story. 

The first part is what I consider to be the strongest part of the game. You are immediately thrown into a hospice with no other explination. The rest of part one is the adventure the two main protaganists go on. The game did a very good job of pushing the story along. Although I did find it hard to relate with Setsumi, girl that goes along. Other than that Part one gets a strong recomendation from me. Most of the issues I have with the game apear in the second half

The "2nd side" more of a preqel if anything helping explain some of what happened in the 1st half. The 2nd side started really good, but ended on a poor note. They introduce my favorite charactor in the game Himeko who is an energetic car enthusiast. She shares and unlikely friendship with Yuka a girly girl who wears frilly clothing. The interactions between the two of them were quite charming leading to ocasional comidic banter. However in the second half she gets replaced by Setsumi, who is far less interesting in almost every way. There could have been an oppertunity to include her again later on however that doesnt really happen. The biggest problem that I have with the 2nd side, is the pointless shoehorning of religion. The ending had far less of an impact on me than it should have because of the constant reminder of the Catholic Church and praying. The whole thing felt like it was being wote by a Catholic, but I checked the notes and the author doesn't consider them selves "among the faithful". In the end however the story was good. even with the ocassional church sceen.

Ultimately I would recomend the whole thing. If you are a Catholic you will probably enjoy it twice as much as I did. Just understand that it's a visual novel and there is  no gameplay. Hence the term visual novel.

15658202.review:
I'm not sure that calling this a visual novel is a great idea. A novel, sure, but as for the visuals they are merely wide-ratio images. After the first few images it gets to the point where they don't really add much. If they had published it as a website/blog, with the images as headers, then I feel the experience would have been better. and in that format you wouldn't need to worry about clicking through each sentence, or dealing with the sentence autoplayer.

As for the story itself, I think its OK. A bit too depressing for my tastes, but it does seem to capture the essence of what it would be like to live with such a condition. The finality of it is hard to handle, but if you want an emotional story, then go for it. Some of the translations are, as expected, occasionally a bit off, but overall it is very good.

As I've said, clicking through the program [calling it a game would be a bit much, considering it is a linear story] can be tedious, and the program itself is a bit odd. The chapters don't seem to run off each other, it takes you back to the main menu after each one finished. And the addition of achievements is clearly an unwarranted gimmick here.

To bring this together, I've not got any problem with the story. But the game that it is wrapped up in is probably better off not on steam.

15657304.review:
[h1]This game was made in 2005. At that time games had been created not for just gaining money.[/h1]

Many people say that it is a visual novel. I don’t think that is the one.

You’ll not find neither plenty of pictures (backgrounds), nor the sharp plot. You’ll not be able to manage the game. Everything you’ll be able to do is read. And I can assure that you would not be indifferent at the end. 

Narcissu 1st & 2nd  — is a history about two people’s life for 1 month. These people are doomed. Even we don’t face people like them every day, they still exist. And there are much of them.

You’ll feel all the experience and all the thoughts of main hero and his “companion”.  To be honest, I can’t exactly tell you who is the main hero of this game — boy, who’s telling us a story, or a girl, whom he is thinking about from almost actually the moment when game starts.

In fact, this game doesn’t even need much of backgrounds and “freedom of choice”, like we have in “Everlasting Summer”. Extremely exciting plot does everything.

By the way, I should say something about backgrounds. They’re not much in here — just 10-15 pictures. But music is matched very accurately. It is the thing that gives us whole atmosphere of the game.

This game has a huge psychological effect. As you can see, it is free. I have noticed that all the nice and soulful games are always being made for a long time by some talented people and finally are free. They’re made not by huge companies.

Never give up. Take your problems easier. Remember: there’s always someone who feels much worse then you right now.

10/10

無料で読めるノベルゲー(1本道)がSTEAMに登場。
日本語対応＋音声付き(音声無しも可)。
人生の終着をテーマにした重暗い話だったかと思います。
内部の章話ごとに細かく分けられているので、

(今回、自分は実績解除のみで作品を読んでいません。)
BGMの曲の出来が素晴らしく、今作の挿入歌+曲は格別です。

邪道ですが本作の実績解除は短時間で可能です。

1＆2話の全エピソード＋エピローグ全て早送りで10分以内に解除が終わるかと思います。

自分はコレと同時に何故か「学校のカイダン」シリーズを思い出します。
本作はかなり内容にヤラレタのを何となく覚えています。

今はBGMとして、挿入歌曲を聴いていますが大変良いです。（*^_^*）

15645722.review:
What I write: 
11/10 for my  eyes which were standing dry after chapter 8. Though finished it a way ago without steam, I still wish to make some hours with steam to make my review persuasive.(LOL) Would recommend Setsumi to my girlfriend, student and project adviser. (though I have none of them)

What I want to write: 
Actually I played Narcissu's app a while ago, approximately 2 years from now on an android phone. It was a warm May afternoon, and I got  a 2 hours off after the swimming class and before after-class curriculum. I had only a mobile phone, no homework, no friends around, and nothing to do but waiting for the curriculum. So I found myself so bored that I have to seek something interesting - except playing games on my phone that  I had cracked for several times. I checked google play store, with the keyword that I've  forgotten, and my focus was caught by an app with a cover of white background and a smiling girl. Its  name was “水仙” (shuixian, means narcissus in Chinese). I downloaded it, thinking it was some kind of Life simulation bishojo game, which was a perfect way of wasting time. That's how I found Narcissu, the Chinese translated version. 

However, it's Narcissu. The result of playing this "Life simulation bishojo game" was that I had totally forgotten what was around me for the next 2 hours, because all my focus was on this novel. No matter how loud guys were when the class was over, no matter how warm the sunshine was, what I  could only feel was a kind of regretting, for something that I could not express at that time. That's Narcissu. I did not cry, but my heart was somehow hollowed at the time I finished it. That is Narcissu.

15634948.review:
Очень хорошая визуальная новелла.
Игрой в прямом смысле её назвать сложно, возможности выбора нет, текст идет линейно.
Технически она очень проста, маленький экран, простые но красивые иллюстрации. (Которые понравятся также тем, кому не нравится аниме как таковое).
Но техническая сторона здесь не главное, главное сюжет. А сюжет здесь такой что даже меня, злостного циника, тронул очень сильно.
Новелла разделена на 2 части, автор (новеллы) рекомендует начинать со второй. Вторая часть это предисловие первой.
История рассказывает о смертельно больных людях, находящихся в хосписе, и проживающих свои последние дни, и свои последние путешествия в дороге под названием жизнь. В небольшой вообщем то новелле подняты многие серьезные темы, о жизни, смерти, предопределенности, о чувствах тех кто уходит навсегда, и тех кто остается.
В рамках короткого обзора эту новеллу не описать. Её надо прочесть, и прочувствовать самому. Каждый найдет в ней свое, но без сомнения она доставит Вам удовольствие, хоть оно и будет сопряжено с тихой, но светлой грустью.
Рекомендую всем.
10 из 10.

P.S: Отдельно хочу отметить саундтрек, который замечательно задает тему. Обычно в играх саунд, отдельно от игры слушать не хочется, здесь же саундтрек, печальный и мелодичный, хочется скачать, и прослушивать под настроение.

15632297.review:
[h1]It is a good type of sadness, named empathy[/h1] 

   This is a review tuned towards those who feel like putting off playing Narcissu 1st & 2nd either because they believe it’s " a boring book", "sounds upsetting", “don’t like manga/anime” or just cheese through in fifteen minutes for the achievements with the hope they might give it a go one nice, quiet afternoon in. Three are misconceptions and the latter… deplorable.

Note:  This has been completed as a review with abstract views, especially due to the game's grave theme. 
This is worth your time, especially as an F2P game (you're missing out)!

* Semi-spoiler alert. 
    Does not contain extensive storylines but will hint at certain basic aspects of the plot which could spoil gameplay a smidgen.

* [b]TL;DR[/b] – [u]A straightforward and conclusive review can be found at the bottom[/u]

[h1]Death of the young affects everyone[/h1]
    Be ready as the very private and personal events of death will unfold before you. It will not drag you to hell or kill you from boredom if you take the time to read it properly. It does a superb job of taking out the gut-wrenching and leaving minimal scars. Whenever young people die in a similar context I am reminded of the anime series, [i]Anohana[/i] (あの日見た花の名前を僕達はまだ知らない。) which I strongly recommend whether you like anime or not as it talks about the issue of loss and death for young adults as is done through Narcissu. It's a theme which requires more love from modern literature and media emphasis. Sharing more consistency with Narcissu is John Green's novel, [i]The Fault in Our Stars[/i] (there is also a film) so that may give you an idea of the amount of heartache and satisfaction Narcissu may offer as a sad but worthwhile read.

[h1]Reminiscent of the best 90s Japanese romance mangas but thankfully reads minus the drama overdrive[/h1]
    Closer to the likes of previously noted, popular modern young adult novels, Narcissu is oddly empowering as many stories like it are even for mature adults. You are a young girl without much time to live but still plenty of life left in you. It is down-to-earth and focuses on realism despite its medical inconsistencies so no character is perfect and there is no right or wrong on the perception of life, death and [spoiler]suicide[/spoiler]. Even the religious slant in Narcissu 2 refreshingly had no bias or distortion. I recently played [i]The Cat Lady[/i], which is a beloved game on Steam also deeply based on death and [spoiler]suicide[/spoiler]. But it had several points where equality disintegrated in a beaker full of acid-ridden negativity (you'll see the logic behind this if you play the game). On the other spectrum, Narcissu, like its title, is honed to a emphatically personal experience in a much more positive way without losing force. 

[h1]The idea of freedom and choice within a world that lacks it[/h1]
    Loss and pain through the death of a loved one is excruciating as well as highly disorientating. Looking back on several personal experiences, it feels distinctly like falling through limbo. It is the most earth shattering and realistic inevitability that could ever happen to any living soul. So it is my belief that many people understandably dislike any variation of such a storyline which hints death and desolation with no escape or way to "win", especially due to the likely sense of powerlessness it makes the player/reader undergo. [u][b]But this is about your death.[/b][/u] One of the main protagonists, you, are a terminally ill character dealing with the side effects of knowing you are dying and your physical being broken down. For those inclined to avoid dealing with thoughts of death, this is a basic and comfortable visual novel to imagine the decisions you may fall upon in the face of death and urge you to grow up from being afraid of thinking onwards to that deep, impending dark hole you're walking towards.

[h1]The absence of interaction in-game, does not detract from the interactivity out of game [/h1]
    Every time I come across a documentary feature or visual novel, I weigh the chances I will find it boring. It's the expected outcome of short films, documentaries, software and visual novels currently available on Steam due only due to the superficially stark contrast they display from the average fully interactive game. Time and time again, I am proved wrong to have ever fretted as sitting in front of a computer screen and clicking through a story is just as culture-driven within its own universe as any game can be and offers the reader a multitude of emotions from which most will benefit from as entertainment. The graphics may be uninspired, the art cute but barely existent, and the translations could have been better (fantastic for F2P) yet you can tell it’s brilliant writing. With any type of reading, nothing beats a smashing story. That very story and the telling of it is what Narcissu excels at. I ended up interacting more deeply with other people who have played this game more than I have through other veritable games. [b]Narcissu is lightly philosophical and a fantastic excuse for a soul-searching expedition.[/b]

[h1] TL;DR & Basic details[/h1]
    [b]TL;DR[/b] - Narcissu 1st & 2nd both bring light to saying goodbye to your life prematurely, on an extremely personal level in the form of a visual novel that lacks visuality/aesthetics and is more towards a breezy but splendid read.

    [b]Basic details[/b] - Depending on a person's reading proficiency, this will take you approximately 5-6 hours to read through 1, 2 and the epilogue once. There are two versions of translations available for the first instalment but only one for the second. I personally found the first translator smoother (especially as it has both 1 and 2, but I read the second translator's version as well) but try both for a few pages to find your own preference. There are also voiced (Japanese) and unvoiced versions. Narcissu 2 has much more voice acting than 1 which only has the bare minimum. Decide which heightens immersion for you. Just as it is with audio books, some will dislike the voice acting (well done and professional). Having studied Japanese for a while and understanding a portion of what is said made reading much swifter. Narcissu 1 is a favourite for many so if you'd just like to read one, that's what I'd recommend. I can only imagine how wonderful it would be to read the original Japanese text as the descriptive writing is first-rate.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
    Ultimately, our protagonists are fighting the fight just like the rest of us. Our instincts to live, and the restrictions we are faced with (death, illness, suffering and loss), ends in discovering choices within those boundaries and our insignificant existences with bound limbs, to instead jump towards the metaphysical freedom and something much more dazzling than any other sign of human existence.


[i]Edited for typing error.[/i]

15609551.review:
A beautiful and moving self pased movie. This free game expertly touches on the topics of terminal illness, suicide, and how a person should act. I would recommend it to anyone who is or has/had a significant person with such an illness. Narcissu doesn't claim to have the answers, but it instead tries to help explain.

The 2nd side is longer than the 1st, but together they add up to roughly 5-6 hours if the voice option is picked.
The soundtrack is amazing.
The art is masterful.
I would recommend being at least 16 years before pushing through Narcissu. The topics are clearly mature (not adult, just very thought provoking).

15606578.review:
Dont do the mistake that I did, that I played this in unvoiced version.

****   ALWAYS PLAY THIS GAME IN VOICED VERSION   ****

--------------------------
> >> Review:
--------------------------
I really liked the story and the translation done by agilis. The translations were proffesional and screams words that are used to their maximum potential. Agilis really used every word in the dictionary he can find to suit the scene. I like the way he used words like "scrap" rather than "retro". 

If you possess a broad vocubulary, I suggest using Agilis' translation, as his employs some but not all of the scenes, deep words not know to the everyday joe. If you dont mind the technicality of the words and want just easy to understand scenes, then you go for gp3^2.

But when in doubt, go for Agilis. 

I also like the music they put into account in the vn. Really powerful music pieces makes the vn's more motionally deppressing. 

One last thing, ALWAYS and ALWAYS play the voiced version. Just like above, dont make the mistake like what I did. I did N1 on unvoiced version. Didn't cry tho, just deppresed by the story. And I felt the urge to do N2 on voiced. And It was significantly better.

Even if you dont understand what they say, the voice acting also compliments the disheartening story through varying tones of their voices. Voice acting is really good. Just play the voiced version, it will save you time. You will know this when you finished the game. ;)


>>>>    TL;DR     <<<<
=================================================================

Overall, I really like the game. The game, when N1 and N2 are both played, are worth more than 4-8 hours. I cant believe that this VN is free. Some will cry, some will be moved. Somehow, I didn't cried, just gloomy and and emotinally moved by the story. Play this game when you have spare time. Its because this game shoudn't be rushed.

SCORE: 9.5/10

What are you waitng for? Go play this game!

15605747.review:
Simply beautiful and sad.

Narcissu is a tale of joy, loneliness, sadness, loss and acceptance. The plot is realistic. There are no super heroes, miracles or happy ending. Instead what is presented is a sad tale about people whose lives have been unkindly cut short and how they deal with it.

Gameplay is more reminiscent to reading a book or watching a movie. There are no choices to make in this game like other visual novels. Instead you simply click to move on to the next scene to read as well as listen to the story. You can choose to listen to a voice version or non-voiced version, which have slighlty altered translations.

The audio is simply heartbreaking. Music is does a marvelous job at setting a sad, tense and happy atmosphere. Thankfully, you can listen to some of the tracks in the "Extras" section. There is only japanese audio, with subtitles provided for other countries.

I highly recommend this game to people who want a good emotional story or keen to read.

15602094.review:
Narcissu is about 2 main characters on their journey towards death. Unfortunately for me and fortunately for those I have served, I was a 'helper', like this game described it, for "3" years. And it brought back many, if not all, emotions I encountered from the patients there, especially desperation and hope.

The lovely piano and its soundtrack adds a lot of depth to the storyline. With that said, it's difficult to determine who is who when there is dialogue. Voice actresses sound the same to me and there is no name assigned to the text they are saying.

Regardless of the downfalls, expect a very realistic narrative and emotional response from each of the characters. This game will humble you very quickly and give you insight on the journey of death that we will all experience one day.

15601630.review:
*SPOILERS AHEAD*


Well, before i start off with this review i would like to first  give my cincerest apology for my previous review which i am editing right now. Only after finishing the first part did i burst in outrage of how the ending is completely unfair and doesnt suit the game at all in any way.But...after finishing what is left of this visual novel, i came to the realization of how blinded i was by my own sense of justice. Yes the game may seem a bit brutal at times but that just comes to show the reality of our lives.It just isnt fair sometimes, but  during those dark periods of our lives even a small spark of light in the darkness can make you even show a....smile. That is exactly what happenned here. With Setsumi experiencing extreme loneliness during most of her life, feeling betrayed by her former friends who just became strangers later on, there was that one person that was able to show her some good parts of life even knowing herself that her life is coming to an end. Himeko.....she was the one who was able to shed the light inside her soul and become a close friend of hers. Despite Hiemko experiencing some of her own mental breakdowns in the past and thus becoming a former Catholic, she still wanted to help Setsumi out because she knew that she was going to live longer than her only because she was 15 years old. Fast forward 5-6 years later after Himekos death, Setsumi was left with an envelope which contained a hefty amount of money and a lot of maps entrusted to her by Himeko herself who wished for Setsumi to travel and experience the world, to "live her life" before it was too late. Even after travelling around and experiencing some parts of Japan with the other protagonist who was unfortunately diagnosed with a simillar type of disease, there was still missing inside of her that the male protagonist just couldnt understand. And finally after arriving to their final destination where they wanted to see the narcissu bloom on the island,which Setsumi learned about from Himeko during the prequel, there finally came the moment when Setsumi just couldnt handle it anymore and started crying after being asked by the male protagonist why she doesnt want to go anywhere anymore with him. By explaining to him that she cant handle hopes getting crushed and wishes not getting granted, that she just decided to give up from the very beginning and tell herself that it is all usseles, he couldnt say anything and stood silent. The day after their conversation he asked Setsumi if she wanted to maybe go around the beach for a bit and had the idea to hand over the bikini she had with her. That was the moment when Setsumi realized that she always wanted to wear thatt bikini but never got the chance to do it. After putting it on, the protagonist wanted to take her picture but....with a smile on her face. There it was when she realized that maybe some wishes can come true and that was one of them...to smile. After posing for a couple of shots and fooling around the beach for a bit she couldnt believe that for the first time she was having...fun. That was it. Later after saying her goodbyes to the male protagonist and being entrusted with his drivers license, she started walking towards to sea to end it all. But before she did that he stopped her to ask her if she wants to be stopped or pushed faster to the water. There it was when she herself wasnt sure bu then she started shedding tears and let out a genuine smile directly aimed at him. That smile itself was the answer to his question. And that is how her life came to an end. That type of ending just shows that Setsumi was confident with her choice because he showed her that some wishes even during those dark times can actualy come true which means that Himeko's prayed has been answered. For Setsumi to smile. Setsumi realized that and knew that her work is done and that she could rest in peace now knowing that her wish did come true in the end. It just comes to show that this one of those endings which tells us that having faith always is a high priority. To know that there is always even a spark of light at the end of the tunnel. From Nello's , Himeko's and Chihiro's prayer being answered, Setsumi finally realized that after all of her suffering , right before the very end of her life, she finally smiled and felt happy for a moment. That was all it took for her to say right before she walked into the sea that it was worth it.

ナルキッソス 1st & 2nd
元は日本の同人ゲームで無料、もちろん日本語に対応しているほか翻訳元によって2つの英語翻訳から選べるという充実ぶり。
病に侵され病院のホスピスに入院することとなった主人公。通称「7階」と呼ばれるその場所に入ったものは、そこで死ぬか自宅で死ぬしかないといわれている場所だった。
そこには長きにわたる入院で生きる何もかもに気力を失っていた女性セツミがいた。彼女と会話になっていない会話を講談室でやりとりする主人公だったが、ある日面会に来た父親が置き忘れた車のカギを持ち出して病院を抜け出し、セツミと共に行く当てのないドライブに出るのであった。
やることもなくブラブラと走っているだけの数日間を過ごしていた二人は、ある時病棟の講談室にあるテレビで見たナルキッソス(スイセンの花)が咲くという淡路島を目指すこととなった。

～ネタバレなので反転。読みたい人は下の行の黒い部分にマウスカーソルを合わせるかクリック

[spoiler]
生きる希望を失い、だがただ何もせず7階でも自宅でも死んでいくことが嫌だった二人が旅を通して目的地へと向かうという目標が生まれるが、それは同時に最後を迎える場所でもあった。死は人間誰にも関わらず用意されている旅の終着地なのだ。それを絶望するのも希望するのも個人の自由ではあるが、このゲームの登場人物は自らの意志で自分の最後をどうするかを決め、死ぬ時となって初めて一人の人間として生きたという実感を感じることとなったのだろう。

15594165.review:
This is actually not a game, strictly speaking, as it is what you define a "kinetic novel", meaning that there are some (also recycled in the 1st part) pictures which accompany the written story (voiced or non-voiced in japanese) and the music. You may or may not enjoy reading this, it is also mostly based on how much english you know, as it is per most of the visual novels. You'll have to do no choices and just sit and "enjoy" the story, which before you ask or think anything, yes, it gets you emotionally and yes, it could be painful.

Personally, I find some passages of the novel a bit too "drama", even resembling things like One Liter of Tears. Aside from writing clichés, I've actually enjoyed - so far, with 2 chapters left from the end of the 2nd part.
The 2nd part in particular, for me, is a bit too overkilled drama in some points, while trying to give a sight of some things of the 1st part.

In the end, it is not the best novel around, neither the most polished (a lot of overused pictures, sounds...) but an impressive one. It really is painful to come back to this game, although you'll probably want to know how the story ends.

15593894.review:
Narcissu 1st is the story about disease, about two young people are dying because it's their fate, right from the start.
Every ordinary thing in our daily life seems to be boring and trivial. But for them, every little thing could make the rest of their days in this world meaningful, an evidence that they are alive even they know it's just temporary and meaningless after all. They've dreamed of a normal life so that they can live, can become anyone that they want. But it's just a dream, a dream which never come true and at the end, Setsumi cried...
You can believe or not, I know exactly how they feel because I used to be like them. Desperate, impotent, regret, hopeless. This is what you feel when your death comes closer and closer. Even the little details they put into the story, the driver license, swimming suit can make me shed a tear because I empathize with their feeling, their pains.
I was too shocked by the ending.[spoiler]But finally, Setsumi has beat her fate. Dying on 7F or at home...nope, none of them[/spoiler]. You know, no matter what happen, we always have a choice and this world isn't fair so we can only choose the way to live and die without regretting...we'll never know what happen tomorrow.

15587252.review:
Narcissu ist eine Visual Novel von Stage-nana in deren Handlung sich alles um einen anonymen Protagonisten schwacher Gesundheit dreht, der kurz nach seinem zwanzigsten Geburtstag mit einer tödlichen Krankheit in ein Krankenhaus in Mito, Ibaraki eingeliefert wird. Dort trifft er Setsumi, ein Mädchen, nur ein paar Jahre älter als er, die ebenfalls tödlich krank ist. Die Novel besteht aus mehreren Teilen, von denen die ersten Beiden hier in einem Spiel kombiniert sind. Im Zweiten werden die Umstände um Setzumi und ihre Vergangenheit genauer beleuchtet. Der dritte Teil ist bereits erschienen, aber noch nicht übersetzt oder auf Steam erhältlich. Hin und wieder wechselt die Erzählerperspektive, um Teile aus der Vergangenheit anderer Charaktere zu erzählen. Die Visual Novel legt seinen Focus auf die Gefühle und Gedanken junger Menschen, die sich mit ihrem unumgänglichen Ende früher befassen müssen, als es jeder verdient hätte.

Alle Teile sind jeweils kurz, mit einer Lesezeit von zwei bis zehn Stunden, haben einen linearen Handlungsstrang und nur ein Ende. Im Gegensatz zu vielen Visual Novels gibt es keine Charakter Sprites zu begutachten. Sie besteht ausschließlich aus CGs. Der Zeichenstil von Charakteren ist recht kindlich, beziehungsweise moe, und der Stil der Hintergründe erinnert an die Nutzung digitalisierter Fotos. Zu Beginn darf der Leser wählen, ob die Novel mit, oder ohne Stimmen gelesen wird. Beides macht einen guten Eindruck, auch wenn ich persönlich gerne die Stimmen und Ausdrücke der japanischen Sprecher und Sprecherinnen höre, die einiges zur Atmosphäre beitragen, wie der grandiose Soundtrack.

Die musikalische Untermahlung passt hervorragend zum Ambiente und der bedrückenden Story und ist in ihrer Qualität hervorragend. Einziger Wehrmutstropfen ist die etwas ungünstige Abmischung der Sounds. Es gilt ein wenig mit den Sound Settings herum zu spielen, bis man die geeignete Mischung aus Musiklautstärke, Geräuschlautstärke und Lautstärke der Sprecher erzielt hat. Mein Tip ist, Musik und Sounds etwas unter mittlere Lautstärke einzustellen und die Sprecher auf voller Lautstärke zu belassen, da sehr häufig leise gesprochen wird.

Im Allgemeinen ist die Technik der Visual Novel mit ihrer Auflösung von Maximal 640x480 und fehlenden Charakter-Sprites, fehlenden Textboxen oder Animationen nicht gerade das Non Plus Ultra, jedoch tut dies dem Erlebnis keinen Abbruch, da der simple Stil hervorragend zur Novel und ihrer Thematik passt. Außerdem verfügt der Anfang des zweiten Teils, nach dem Prolog, ein wundervoll gestaltetes Intro, dass über fehlende Animationen während der Novel durchaus hinweg tröstet. Wem also Grafik nicht all zu wichtig ist, kann sich auf eine kleine, gute und sehr bewegende Geschichte gefasst machen.

Geeignet ist die Novel für alle, die sich – unabhängig des Alters – mit Tod und Verzweiflung auseinandersetzen können. Der bedrückende Unterton ist jedoch nichts für jene, die mit Schwermut nicht gut umgehen können. Für alle anderen jedoch ein Machwerk, dass definitiv einen Blick wert ist, zumal die ersten beiden Teile auf Steam kostenlos zu lesen sind.

... on that very day of winter ...

This is a story of disease and suffering; of medication and adverse effects; of thoracotomy scars and cellular poisons; of the living who cannot help but to die and of the dying who cannot help but to live; of a resting place other than "on 7F" or "at home".

This is a story of so many things.

But most of all ...

this is a story all about how
My life got flipped-turned upside down
And I'd like to take a minute
Just sit right there
I'll tell you how I became the prince of a town called Bel Air

In west Philadelphia born and raised
On the playground was where I spent most of my days
Chillin' out maxin' relaxin' all cool
And all shootin some b-ball outside of the school
When a couple of guys who were up to no good
Started making trouble in my neighborhood
I got in one little fight and my mom got scared

I don't think so

15566464.review:
This is truly awful. Very little effort has gone into this and it shows. What particularly annoyed me was the terrible translation. Not so much spelling mistakes, but grammatical nightmares. Badly constructed and run-on sentences, confusing tenses, coupled with exceedingly poor punctuation, all combined to twist my mind into knots when I should have been enjoying a leisurely read. In a visual novel you would think language to be the most important factor, but often you are distracted enough in trying to make sense of the sentences. I really didn't think that would be where the user participated when I downloaded the game.

Because there is often a confused frame of reference you can be left in the dark over who is doing what exactly? "But they told me: that I was going to die." Who and why a colon? "It was the only thing (word) that left my mouth from beginning to end." "There was no way to escape it it seemed." "It seemed there was no way to escape it." Is a much less complicated construction. I did consider the developer used a young teenager for the role, and had done an expert job of replicating their moderate language skills. Soon however she reveals her age to be 20 years.

There is very little to do in the game, other than advance the text and it's lucky the developer provided a save feature. The story is tedious and extremely boring and the images add very little depth.

I'm not against visual novels because I thought Depression Quest was very well done and had some very interesting dialogues and user-participation. There's nothing like that here, and even though it's free it's a hard novel to get through.

15545181.review:
This isn't a game. It is a visual novel. Such a format is rather new to me and I was skeptical. It seemed to me that a lack of material in the form of words would make visual novels just incredibly short books, the lack of mechanics would make the genre incredibly boring games, and the comparitive lack of visual information would make the genre rather drab movies.

Well, it turns out I was very wrong. Narcissu 1st and 2nd are awesome just as they are. The background music does add significantly to the experience, and its pacing would not be nearly as effective to me in a film or book (and it certainly wouldn't fit a game).

It is a moving story about young people in palliative care and how they decide to live, and die. That doesn't really do it justice though. Another review described it better: "This is a story of disease and suffering; of medication and adverse effects; of thoracotomy scars and cellular poisons; of the living who cannot help but to die and of the dying who cannot help but to live; of a resting place other than "on 7F" or "at home"

There really is no reason not to give this story a try. You won't regret doing so.

15536898.review:
[i]This is a story of disease and suffering; of medication and adverse effects; of thoracotomy scars and cellular poisons; of the living who cannot help but to die and of the dying who cannot help but to live; of a resting place other than "on 7F" or "at home".[/i]

Usually I would start a review with some sort of story hook, an attempt to use my own words to evoke the kind of atmosphere you can expect from the full experience, something to show you at a glance whether it could really speak to you or whether you would not connect with it at all. In the case of [b]Narcissu 1st & 2nd[/b], I feel that no matter how long I try, I will not be able to top the original summary by [i]Insani[/i] (quoted above and throughout this review), the fan translation group that first brought [i]Narcissu[/i] to English-speaking audiences. Instead I will just quote their writing where appropriate and dive straight into the facts myself.

[i]Narcissu[/i] and its sequel [i]Narcissu Side 2nd[/i] are rather famous kinetic novels (meaning they have no branching story or player choices) with a strong legacy in the VN community. They are known for their use of minimalist visuals, mostly showing [url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=298887473]backgrounds with no character sprites[/url] or even [url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=431424867]just a gray void[/url], with only very few [url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=315150492]character CGs[/url] inbetween. The soundtrack relies heavily on [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7wJOCu3PhHg]piano pieces[/url], but also makes use of [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lSpUAfnT7B0]other instruments[/url] in some places, and features two [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=28kscHogQcI]title tracks[/url] with Japanese vocals. The engine shows its age in some aspects and does not have a fullscreen mode for example, but apart from that it has everything you'd expect, including save states and a soundtrack menu. As a reader, you have the choice between two different English translations or the original Japanese script, and you can opt to listen to the Japanese voice acting if you so choose.

[i]Imagine what it would be like to have your entire life -- your friends, your family, your interests, your loves, your hatreds, your future -- all taken away from you in a single instant. Imagine a hard, lumpy bed, a noise-filled ward, the sharp sting of needles entering your flesh at all hours of the day, the indignity of being woken up just as you are about to fall asleep for incessant vital statistics measurements, the doctors whose names you don't know (but that's okay, because they don't remember your name, either; they just remember you as "the non-small cell lung carcinoma in room 6"), and your own name, your very own name, that you have just about forgotten.[/i]

[i]Then you might have some clue as to what it is like to be dying in a hospital.[/i]

It would be off the mark to describe [i]Narcissu[/i] as an "emotional rollercoaster" since the concept would imply lots of ups and downs, but even though [i]Narcissu[/i] ends on a bittersweet note of resolution, it is pretty much devoid of "up" moments. VN connoisseurs might note that this places it in the [i]utsuge[/i] genre, everyone else seeking more stories like it now has a keyword to search by.

The story is about an unnamed young man who [url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=254584693]falls terminally ill[/url]. After all venues of hope are exhausted, he is moved to the hospice ward of the local hospital, where he meets a girl of about his age who conveys to him the unwritten rules of the inhabitants of the [url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=253490566]7th floor[/url], of those who are going to die. The two begin a series of awkward non-interactions that culminate in their decision to reject the dichotomy of dying either in the hospital or at home, which kicks off the main arc of the story.

The way that [i]Narcissu[/i] hones in on its themes with every fiber of its being is both its strongest asset and biggest liability. Everything about it, from the background visuals to the character interactions, is teeming with the drabness that you would expect from a story about young people in palliative care, which is not at all a melodramatic "woe is me" caricature of exaggerated sadness and self-pity, but a cold collage of loss and hopelessness rooted in questions that no human should have to ask themselves, such as: What does it even mean to be alive if there can be nothing to look forward to? Both main characters' actions and non-actions need to be viewed through this lens to have any hope of being understood.

In that sense, [i]Narcissu[/i] as a piece of literature is more demanding of your sense of empathy than many other games and visual novels: It could easily be misunderstood as a story trying to show "normal" people what it is like to be terminally ill by taking their hands and walking them through the experience, but in actuality it's closer to a slice-of-life story about people who are terminally ill, that asks you to make the necessary mental steps towards those people on your own if you wish to understand them. In short: This story isn't written for you, it's written for its main characters.

One example that I can give without veering too far into story spoilers is Setsumi's attitude towards the protagonist. She initially comes across as standoffish and rude, and there's the tacit expectation of a pivotal moment where she finally starts to open up so the "proper" story can start, but that moment never comes. Where a less patient or empathetic reader might leave the story unsatisfied, we can instead take the opportunity to examine Setsumi's behavior with her medical situation in mind, and ponder the way that human relationships develop. Most of us go through life every day making small passing connections to people, but only once in a while do we meet someone we like enough to allow ourselves to be vulnerable around them (which takes courage) in hopes of forging a lasting connection that we can depend on in the future. But what, then, if there quite literally [i]is[/i] no future? Suddenly there is no point in opening up to anyone new. Why bother taking the risk of potentially getting hurt if we will not live to see the reward?

The novel doesn't spell these details out to you, it asks you to understand the characters on the basis of their actions. Questions like why having a goal is suddenly such a big deal to the protagonist are left up to interpretation. The combination of strong characterization (which if you've seen my previous VN reviews you already know I am crazy for) and partially unapproachable writing is not for everyone, especially not if you are looking for light entertainment, but there is a lot of substance to it for people willing to make the effort.

In summary, [i]Narcissu[/i] is a great visual novel that can be genuinely rewarding to read, but is ill-suited for those of us with short attention spans.

[i]This is a story of so many things.[/i]

[i]But most of all ...[/i]

[i]This is the story[/i]

[i]of a girl whose heart was standing still[/i]

[i]and a boy whose breath was being stolen away,[/i]

[i]both of whom die.[/i]

15488059.review:
Released in 2005, Narcissu is a free visual novel created by Stage-nana. There are two parts to the VN, Narcissu and Narcissu Side 2nd. They are complementary to each other and I highly recommend reading both in order. If you don't read it in order... well it will probably be confusing.
It's very short taking about 3 hours or so, depending on how fast you read and whether you want to listen to all the voice acting.

Visuals:
Art is very minimalistic, and the backgrounds only cover about 1/3 of the screen
Kinda disappointing, but being a free game I can hardly complain.
While there aren't too many backgrounds and CG, the game is fairly short and takes place in only a few places.
So it completely makes sense. There are very very few character CGs and when do appear, it is just at the right time, and at the right moments to complement the story. Super minimialistic, yet effective in it's own way. 
Some say silence is an important part to music, and certainly applies here as well.

Sound:
Voice acting is good. Nothing outstanding but each voice fits the character. There aren't too many characters in the first place, but the voice actresses do a good job. 
On the Soundtrack, it is quite beautiful. All the tracks greatly add to the ambience; although a bit depressing to listen to alone. For such a short game, there are lots of different tracks. I've seen longer VN with only half the tracks that this game has. 12 songs for the first part, and 14 for the second for a grand total of 26. 
It even incudes a few vocal tracks! 
One complaint I have is the abrupt cuts in music during scene change, or at the end of a scene. I wish it had some sort of fade. The sudden stop to the music kinda kills the mood the game has. 

Story:
There are two parts to the story, Narcissus  and Narcissus Side 2nd
The first part is sort of like an introduction, but the 2nd is what completes the story as a whole.
While it is possible to only play the first part, you owe it to yourself to complete the second. Trust me, you'll feel a lot less depressed :(
The second part definitely wraps up the story and leaves with a glimmer of hope.
The plot is definetly not the main focus here. It is more about the life of each character and their emotions. Struggling with death and hopelessness. Again, going with minimalistic art, I'd say the story is very minimalistic as well. A lot of things are unsaid, giving a lot of freedom of interpretation for the readers. I quite liked this style, and allowed for some thought provoking dialogue. 

Beautifully written, and thought provoking, it makes you wonder what I would do in that situation. Could I have the power or courage to be hopeful in despair? 

If you enjoy Visual Novels, then go ahead and try it out!
It's free and there is nothing to lose~

15403322.review:
I don't like how the story is presented.  To start, the translation options are cryptic, so the best option for your language is unknown when you start the game.  I chose Insani because it was the only one I thought was legible as far as its logo goes.  It turned out to be an English translation, but the voice was still in the original language, which meant the voice meant nothing to me.  This is an overly glorified e-book, so I hate the empty, wasted space and the very tiny window.  It seems unnecessary to confine the user/player/reader to a game window when they could be reading the book more comfortably from a full-screen e-reader app.  Oh, yeah, you can't full-screen this 'game'!  Hell, it would be better if I could skip to a specific portion of the story since there's no save option or any kind of actual gameplay (no choices).

Finally, the pictures are generic and have very little to do with the text.  You will see the same images more than once and not really understand why they're shown to you at all.  It's ridiculously lazy storytelling in my opinion.  I expected more relevant imagery from a visual novel.  In the past, I used to watch visual novels like this one which were amazing, but this one just isn't worth my time.  It's boring and implemented poorly.  I've seen better in free Flash animations back in the Newgrounds glory days! Yes, it's free, as well, but it's a big waste of time when you can get better experiences elsewhere without much effort.

15390335.review:
Enredo

O cenário inicial é um hospital católico, no qual o sétimo andar é a única ala do hospital onde os pacientes não recebem nenhum tipo de tratamento, pois é lá onde ficam os casos sem solução.

O protagonista é mandado para lá e encontra uma menina chamada Setsumi, ele percebe o quanto é chato residir naquele local, mas ele está acostumado pois em sua vida toda ele passou de um hospital para outro. Ele se interessa por Setsumi, pois ela é igual a ele. Um dia ela diz que não quer morrer no 7F e nem em sua casa. Em um ato de impulsividade o protagonista rouba o carro do pai e começa a viajar pelo Japão com ela, procurando um lugar para morrer.

Narcissu não te passa uma grande mensagem que te ensina a seguir em frente, muito menos é um romance sobre duas pessoas que não tem nada a perder. É uma simples história sobre pacientes terminais e como eles lidam com a morte.

Quando lidar com a realidade é muito difícil as pessoas procuram um jeito de se manter fora dela, Setsumi faz isso ao nunca demonstrar suas emoções, enquanto para o protagonista o mundo real é só uma visão, como se ele estivesse longe observando tudo que acontece, ele não se importa com nada, o que o fez ver a realidade por algum tempo foi a apatia de Setsumi.

Durante grande parte da história o protagonista não tem rosto nem voz. Acredito que essa escolha foi feita para poder colocar o leitor dentro da história, fazendo você se sentir como se fosse o personagem. O autor de Narcissu disse que, um dia ele simplesmente quis escrever e saíu Narcissu, se você vê alguma mensagem aqui, isso é com você, pois ele não tinha nenhuma intenção de mostrar algo a mais com o seu texto.

É uma história curta e interessante, cerca de 5/6 horas de leitura. O grande atrativo dela é sua narrativa, você se sente curioso para saber o que vai acontecer, como essas pessoas que vivem na sombra da morte irão desfalecer. Existem situações até um pouco engraçadas, ao fugir do hospital o protagonista se preocupa muito com a falta de dinheiro, várias vezes ele acaba pensando em roubar dinheiro para manter a viagem.

Acredito que o autor dessa história deveria vendê-la por pelo menos uns R$3,00. Ele gastou tempo com isso e existe uma certa qualidade.

Parte técnica

Narcissu é uma visual novel, um livro digital. O que há de se avaliar em quesitos técnicos? Bem, nestes livros digitais existem dublagem, várias ilustrações são empregadas para mostrar o cenário e uma trilha sonora toca a todos os momentos, as vezes os desenhos até se movem.

Em quase todos os quesitos Narcissu é bem abaixo da média, as artes são repetitivas, tendo em vista que é um projeto gratuito de pouco orçamento, faz sentido. A única voz presente é a de Setsumi, uma dublagem boa mas, existem poucas falas. Combinaram a personalidade reclusa de Setsumi com essa limitação orçamental, ela fala frases curtas, rápidas e sucintas durante toda a história, em alguns momentos as gravações são repetidas, para ficar ainda mais fácil para os desenvolvedores.

Não existem animações. O único quesito técnico que vai além do medíocre é a trilha sonora, ela é muito melancólica, combina perfeitamente com o clima e as situações do enredo.

Narcissu 2nd.

Na verdade existe até um Narcissu 3rd, só que esse não tem relação com o primeiro.

A versão do Steam vem com dois jogos na verdade, até agora só falei do primeiro porque não gostei muito do segundo.

Na parte técnica ele é muito superior ao primeiro. Existem muito mais ilustrações, existem mais de três vozes mostrando que o elenco cresceu, e as músicas continuam tão boas ou até melhores. Provavelmente o primeiro jogo teve um relativo sucesso para o segundo ser desta forma.

O que eu não gostei foi do enrendo mesmo. Dessa vez ele não é rápido nem minimalista igual ao primeiro jogo, ele tenta te mostrar uma história melhor desenvolvida sobre os acontecimentos que antecederam o primeiro Narcissu. Ele é legal, fala mais sobre a experiência de se trabalhar em uma hospital, como as pessoas que trabalham com pacientes terminais se sentem, e uma outra visão de como lidar com a morte. Porém achei a história bem tediosa, ela é beeeeeeem lenta e ao final dela, igual ao primeiro jogo, não existe uma mensagem clara. Se você viu algo, bom pra você.

É totalmente gratuito. Se você gosta de ler e quer algo diferente confira Narcissu 1st&2nd no Steam!

Postado originalmente em: http://1048596.blogspot.com.br/

15263966.review:
Prolog: Joa, scheint ganz nett zu sein.
Kapitel 1: Wow, da steckt jede Menge Potential drin!
Kapitel 2: Ok, was kommt jetzt?
Kapitel 3-7: Langeweile pur.
Kapitel 8: Wenigstens haben sie das Ende nicht versaut.

Narcissu 1st&2nd ist die erste Visual Novel, die ich gespielt habe. Das man hier kein Actionfeuerwerk erwarten kann war mir von Anfang an klar, was bleibt also? Story, Soundtrack und Visuals.

Die Story bietet wahnsinnig viel Potential. Das Problem dabei: Es wird weggeworfen. 
Der namenlose Protagonist bekommt kurz nach Bestehen seiner Führerscheinprüfung mitgeteilt, dass er an einer unheilbaren tödlichen Krankheit leidet. Im Krankenhaus, in das er eingewiesen wird, gibt es den "7th Floor", ein Station, in der ausschließlich Patienten wie er unterkommen. Zwar ist es möglich, die Station zu verlassen, wenn es der Gesundheitszustand zulässt, allerdings wird man garantiert wieder zurückkommen. Dort trifft er das Mädchen Setsumi, die ebenfalls sterbenskrank ist. Irgendwann beschließen beide, dass sie weder im Krankenhaus noch zu Hause bei ihren Familien sterben wollen und fliehen gemeinsam im silbernen Coupe des Vaters des Protagonisten. 
Das war die Story bis Kapitel 2. Danach geht es steil bergab. In einem Satz zusammen gefasst: Die beiden fahren (zunächst noch ohne zu wissen wohin eigentlich, später mit dem Ziel, ein Narzissenfeld, dass sie im Fernsehen gesehen haben, zu besuchen) durch die Gegend, klauen sich hin und wieder Geld und Kleidung zusammen,..und das wars auch schon. Jegliche Situationen, die Spannung hervorrufen könnten, werden abgetötet:[spoiler]Kein Geld zum tanken? Setsumi hat plötzlich mehr als genug davon. Kein Attest, um ein Medikament zu kaufen? Es einfach klauen und wegfahren.[/spoiler]. Wenn man dann nach endlos lang(weiligen) fünf Kapitel endlich am Ende angelangt ist freut man sich schon fast, dass es vorbei ist. Das finale achte Kapitel gibt der Geschichte zwar ein würdiges Ende, welches aber durchaus vorhersehbar ist. Ich hatte mir sogar ein solches Ende gewünscht und es war auch der einzige Moment, der ansatzweise die in anderen Reviews beschrieben "feels" hervorrief.

Die einzigen relevanten Charaktere sind der Protagonist und Setsumi.
Über ihn erfährt man fast nichts. Er ist Student, hat Vater, Mutter und eine kleine Schwester sowie gerade seine Führerschein bekommen. Weder Aussehen noch Name werden erwähnt, über sein komplettes Leben breitet sich ein Mantel des Schweigens. Dieser Umstand plus die Tatsache, dass seine Gedanke und Gefühle allenfalls oberflächlich behandelt werden macht es sehr schwer, sich mit ihm zu identifizieren.
Setsumi hat da wesentlich mehr zu bieten. Das fängt damit an, dass sie einen Namen hat, man erfährt sogar wie sie aussieht, später auch etwas über ihre Hobbies und Vorlieben. Sie spricht wenig und ihre Gefühle sowie ihr Verhalten wird nur rudimentär aus der Sicht des Protagonisten beschrieben. Allerdings gibt es ein paar Passagen, in denen uns Einblick in ihren Kopf gewährt wird und wir mehr über ihre Gedanken und Motivation erfahren. Diese kurzen Abschnitte zeichnen jedoch das Bild einer komplexen und durchdachten Persönlichkeit, die sich ihrer Lage durchaus bewusst ist und sich aktiv mit ihr auseinander setzt.
Allerdings wird das sehr kurz gehalten. Warum? Warum den langweiligen, oberflächlichen Typen zum Protagonisten machen anstatt des Mädchens, das viel mehr Möglichkeiten bietet?

Die Dialoge sind kurz und verhältnismäßig leer. Wer hier eine philosophische Auseinandersetzung mit dem Thema Tod und Gewissheit des Sterbens erwartet wird enttäuscht. Sehr viel verschenktes Potential.

Kommen wir also zum Soundtrack. Da gibt es qualitativ nichts zu meckern. Die Musik ist wunderschön und schafft es, die jeweilige Stimmung gut zu untermalen. Ein Musterbeispiel dafür, wie man Musik richtig einsetzt. Einziger Kritikpunkt: Es wiederholt sich schnell und Soundeffekte wie zum Beispiel das Starten des Motors oder das Zuschlagen von Türen wirken aufgesetzt.
Es gibt die Möglichkeit zwischen "unvoiced" und "voiced". Oder besser gesagt "ohne Stimme" oder "Mit Stimme, die vor sich hin nuschelt und alle 5 Minuten einen Satz sagt, der länger als drei Wörter ist". An der Leistung der Synchronsprecherin (der Protagonist hat keinen Sprecher bekommen) gibt es nichts auszusetzen, es wirkt nur ein bisschen verschwendet, da die meisten Sätze nur aus 1-3 Wörtern bestehen und sich ständig wiederholen.

Bleiben also die Visuals. Einfach gehalten, ein Streifen im Querformat plus eine, maximal drei Zeilen Text. Die Bilder wiederholen sich häufig, teilweise angepasst (das selbe Bild mit Rotstich wenn es Abend und Blaustich wenn es Nacht ist).

An den zweiten Teil hab ich mich gar nicht erst ran getraut.

Alles in allem keine Empfehlung. Vielleicht bin ich mit zu hohen Erwartungen an die Sache herangegangen, aber die Story war einfach eine Enttäuschung für mich. Und die ist eben der Hauptbestandteil einer Visual Novel.

15069373.review:
Narcissu (& Narcissu Side 2nd) is a beautiful, but sad visual novel game. The plot of both revolve around characters that have been admitted to a hospital level called the "7th Floor." This hospital floor is not your typical floor in a hospital (if that makes any sense). It's a "hospice," a place where people who suffer from incurable diseases and will eventually die go to live out the rest of their days. Each story is different from the other, and play out different from each other. However, they are both connected and intertwine with one another. 

Narcissu Side 2nd is the prequel to Narcissu. Narcissu Side 2nd tells the story of the relationship between two girls and basically how they spend the summer together. However, they both suffer from the same or similar disease that has no cure and will eventually kill them. This story is about Setsumi (who is a main character in the original Narcissu) and Himeko (Setsumi's new, cheery "deathrow" friend). The story is told primarily from the perspective of Setsumi, but at times switches to Himeko as she explains events in her past. At different points in the story, we learn alittle about the two. We learn about Setsumi's family, Himeko's family, Himeko's past, etc. There's alot more I could mention, but I don't want to give away too much. Just know that, like the original, this is a beautiful, sad, and whimsical quote-on-quote "game." This story also has the same beautiful and heart-felt music from Narcissu, as well as some new pieces which are just as good. Art style is also the same, although it seems there are more images in this version and they are of better quality. Dialogue is well written just like in the original. And as with Narcissu, I did almost cry towards the end of this story. More so on the verge of tears than Narcissu. The story, overall, I feel is BETTER than the original. There's a lot more depth and substance added to this story than the first Narcissu. However, this comes at the cost of greatly increasing the amount of chapters to read. While in the first Narcissu there were 7-8 chapters (including prologue), Narcissu Side 2nd has a whopping 20 chapters (including prologue)! So, a downside to this story is it's a lot longer than the original. Another potnetial downside to this story, which mostly pertains to how "sensitive" you are towards religion, is there's a fair amount of talk about God and Catholicism. I only bring this up because some people may hate the constant mention of God (i.e. if you are a nonworshiper of God or just hate talk of religion in general), and/or may hate how Catholics can be portrayed in this story (there are times in the story where a character tries to disown their Catholic past or ways; there are also times when characters describe Catholicism in a somewhat negative light). This aspect didn't bother me, but it is worth mentioning for others as a warning. Still, a great prequel to a great, original visual novel game.

Narcissu is the orginal story, or at least the one that was released first. This story follows the journey of two 7th Floor patients to a special destination. What is this "special place" and why are they going there? Well, you'll have to read the story to find out. The two patients are an unamed male patient and Setsumi. The story is told mostly from the perspective of the male patient, but a few times Setsumi narrates some of her life's story. This story is essentially that of a road trip story, but still good none the less. The music in this game is well-composed. Each track is beautiful and compelling. The art style is good. Slightly low budget looking, but still good to look at. The dialogue is well-written, and provokes many philosophical questions from the reader. While I said in my analysis of Narcissu Side 2nd it had less substance, the story of Narcissu is still a great story. I literally almost cried at the end. The characters were portrayed well and were very interesting. Overall, a good story and a good starting point for many other good stories within this universe to come.

All in all, this series is great. Two beautiful, yet sad stories in one beautiful, yet sad universe. The only problems I have with both of the stories is there is some heavy repetition (which can be annoying at times) and reading both stories back-to-back makes for one long reading experience (at least for me it did). I'm very inexperienced when it comes to visual novel games, and didn't expect to spend around 15 hours just reading both of these stories! I thought this series of stories would've been significantly shorter, but boy was I wrong!lol Still, I reccomend you "trudge" through those long hours to uncover a beautiful, intertwining story. As far as which one you should play first depends on your personal preference. The author of both stories reccomends you read the prequel then the original. However, I reccomend you read the original then the prequel. In my opinion, reading the prequel after the first game is a better way to experience the story. The prequel, essentially, fills in all the holes and makes many references to the first game. Seeing how the author wove all these intricate details from the first game into the story and showing how they made their appearance in the original Narcissu is very interesting. This particular analysis can only be done by reading the original first. Not only that, but I feel coming from the prequel to the original may dissapoint a few people. Like I said, Narcissu lacks substance in comparison to Narcissu Side 2nd. So, people may be let down when the original has a lot less story depth than the prequel. It may just feel kinda empty to them. Narcissu was, essentially, the foundation of the Narcissu "universe." So, it's understandable why that story felt alittle more bare bones. The prequel simply took all the good things from Narcissu and built upon them, making the story all the more better. But, still, the ultimate decision of in what order you read is left up to you. Me, I probably WOULD have read the prequel first then the original if I had known Side 2nd was a prequel. But I'm still ok with the order in which I read both. Anyhow, this is a visual novel game that I HIGHLY recommend. A lot of thought, love, and care was put into both of these games and it shows. And the best part of this game/games is...they're free! So, definitely check them out. You'll more than likely love them.:)

P.S. Also, as of March 26, 2015 the acheivements STILL do not work.:/

15009406.review:
[h1]終末医療、死に向き合い生きるを知る[/h1]

[table]
  [tr]
    [th]総評[/th]
    [td]物語を通して自分の「これから」を考える、これぞノベルゲーム[/td]
  [/tr]
[/table]
[list]
  [*] 無料でプレイ可能、完全日本語対応
  [*]ドラマチックで劇的な展開はなく、ただ淡々と死へと向き合う物語
  [*]淡泊なビジュアルにむしろ雰囲気を添えるゲーム内音楽
[/list]

終末医療、ただ生命の尽きる場所――ホスピス。
ゲームを終えた時、自らのこれからの生き方を考えざるを得ない物語。


[h1]目的も未来さえも持たない彼らはただ病院を逃げ出す[/h1]

知ることは死ぬこと、とはよく言ったものでありまさにこの作品でそれを感じる。

病院で死ぬのかそれとも自宅で死ぬのか、そのどちらも拒み逃げ出した主人公とヒロイン。
未来のない二人が「死」というものに向き合い、プレイヤーにすら向き合わせる。

人間とはこう生きるものだ、などといったメッセージの押しつけではない。
ただ彼らの選択を見届け自身であればどのような選択をするだろうかと問いかける。

無意識に考えることを避けてきた「いつかは死ぬ」ということに対して、
彼らの選択を見たことで無関心ではいられない。答えはない。

感動という感動を呼ぶ作品ではないが、ノベルゲームの一つの到達点だろう。


[h1]ビジュアルとサウンド、操作性[/h1]

ビジュアルに関して、ほぼ全編を通して淡泊な背景と文字が描かれるだけで
「ビジュアルノベル」としての作品を求めているのならば注意したい。

サウンドは素晴しく、BGMは物語に寄り添う良き見届け人となっている。
ぜひサウンドトラックで静かで優しさのある曲を聴いてみて欲しい。

古臭く荒削りなユーザーインターフェースは確かに現在では不親切だ。
最近のヴィジュアルノベル作品であればついているだろう機能はほとんどない。
UIの古臭さがむしろ淡泊さの演出に一役買っていると言えなくないが、
最低限の機能がついているのみで、操作性は悪い。


[h1]プレイするべきか否か[/h1]

物語を見届けた際の読後感、虚脱感。
胸の奥深くに確かに刻まれるような感慨をぜひ感じて欲しい。

俗に言う「萌えイラスト」を苦手に感じる人もいるだろうが
それらが登場する機会はゲーム中ほとんどなく、
純粋にこの作品のテーマが気になった人には是非ともお勧めしたい。

本作はノベルゲームが到達する一つのゴールを示した作品だ。
