10590554.review:
"Right in the feels. Well worth the free download." - Me

Anyways... my gosh this is an amazng story. I felt connected to the character, and I had yet to see her face. 15 minutes in, I already was halfway to tears. This is the most sad "game" I have ever played. This isn't an interactive game, it's more of a narrative, and a damn good one at that.

I don't want to give any spoilers of the story, because every single word captures your attention, and you are glued to the screen for the first 3 chapters...then you turn the game off 'cus you dont want to start crying. But basically, the story is about a girl who at a very young age is striken withh illness, and has to spend 2/3 of her waking life in the hospital. when she is a young high-school student, she has very few, if any, friends left from her youth. se wakes up one morning after a driving test to a searing pain in her chest, and it's back to the hospital for a while :( . She is given a very fancy room on a new floor sh hasnt been on before; she gets the room to herself (as opposed to regular rooms in Japanese hospitals which have 5-8 people in them), it has a nice lounge, big open ceilings... th windows dont open... the nurses don't walk through... oh my lord. They are leaving her to die :'(... and thats where I will stop telling you.

So far, and I havent gotten all the way through the story, its an 11/10. Absolute masterpeice of story telling. The music is amazing too. As for the game play... like I said, it's not a game.

Narcissu is one of the best Visual Novels I've ever played, which is odd because it lacks a staple feature of the genre in having no choices.Reading the author's notes he states that he wanted this VN to flow like a movie and have good pacing which really adds to it more than it takes away. The story has more meaning behind it than just tear-jerking/FEELS, and the minimalistic art makes you feel like your a bystander listening in instead of looking at talking heads for hours. After playing both Narcissu 1 and 2, I feel that 1 has a better story and has a stronger experience behind it, but 2 is better produced and has a sadder story. Narcissu 2nd definitely makes you feel for Setsumi more in part 1, and gives you some insight into how she feels.

      I think I should mention that the author states in the notes he would like people to play 2nd before 1st because it's the chronological order. I personally played 1st before 2nd as I played 1st when it was first translated by insani a few years ago. But it definitely would probably be a more powerful experience if you played 2nd before 1st, knowing what happens kind of gave me a weird feeling, it's hard to explain, but I think it would make the 1st game an even greater experience if you had the build up of 2nd still in your mind.

[b] Art: [/b] simple, yet evocative
[b] Plot: [/b] Simple, predictable, yet properly detailed

Due to several reasons, Friday nights are an important time for me, and I have a tradition of trying to get myself overdosed with emotions at least once during each of those. This task had become easier ever since I'd discovered visual novels, and I can assure you that Narcissu did the job this last Friday.

10161181.review:
Narcissu is a classic amongs Visual Novels.

This is the story of a guy being terminally ill. Once admitted into the hospital he meets another patient, Setsumi. She is, like him, going to die. However, both of them want to die somewhere else than in the hospital. They will escape, and travel through a few prefectures of Japan. This is their story. Up until the very end.

Do not expect this story to be any kind of funny. This is very emotionnal and you might probably cry. The storytelling is good enough. Two differents translations are available, and you can choose to activate the voices or not.
I read this visual novel a long time ago. Voices and episode 2 were not available at the time.

I do strongly recommend this "game" to anyone wanting to try the Visual Novel genre. This VN, is linear and there are no choices. No interactivity. Technically, this is a subgenre of Visual Novel called a Kinetic Novel. You just read. And do nothing else. Narcissu is however very minimalistic. There are not many pictures compared to other visual novels. Please do not be rebuked, and read, immerse yourself in the story. Like you would for any good book.

This is very close to reading a comic book, except you have music, voice and -- sometimes -- animated pictures. You have to experience at least one visual novel in your life, the same way you should play an RTS or FPS if you haven’t done so. This genre is not well known enough, it's kinda sad.
A lot of other visual novels exists and are masterpieces. This is a good start for anyone not knowing what this media is.

Since Narcissu is Free, do not miss this opportunity, and try it. You will hate it or love it. But, you have to try.

As a litmus test on whether you will enjoy Narcissu or not, imagine yourself picking up a book at a bookstore.  The "About this game" section is the back of the book and the pictures are the front cover of the book.  If you like it and want to continue reading, go on and download the game.  More likely than not, you will enjoy the game.  If not, then you should move on.

I've finished Narcissu 1,2 and 3 before 1 and 2 even got green-lit. Tomo Kataoka did a great job for it. Hopefully this will make people read more visual novels. I see this as an opportunity for more visual novel titles to be up here.

The story was beautifully written and it wasn't in any case forced drama. What I like about this visual novel is it's story is feels almost in touch with reality and not something that is far-fetched. One might think otherwise but it has a natural feel about it. The OST used was also rather smooth and it did great enhancing the mood and atmosphere of the story as it progress. I don't know how well the translations were but Tomo Kataoka did a good job. I hope the translators who translate this don't pull down the quality. It's simply a masterpiece, something not many visual novels could achieve. I for one, recommend this visual novel for visual novel readers. Unless you dislike nakige and utsuge, this visual novel should be a very good read. It isn't very long either so it should be picked up even if one doesn't have loads of spare time as this visual novel is considerably shorter than other visual novels.

I don't want to post any spoilers so I shan't say much about how the story is but I truly recommend this visual novel. 10109983.review:
【死中窥生。】
水仙。说是玩，用看更合适，因为是无选项无操作的视觉小说，娓娓道来两个身罹绝症的人最后那段时光，以及最终如何面对死亡。平淡叙事，没有大起大落，但能感受到那种生的气息被一点点抽离，死亡越走越近的无力感和绝望。
有人选择完成心愿后平静面对，有人逃离医院以自己的方式结束。

会去想如果是自己该如何。

肉体饱经折磨，简单不过的日常却已渐行渐远，自己与亲人的希望幻想被一次次打击，最终万念俱灰，只剩下一个代表结束的倒计时。
万千留恋不舍，终于懂得哪怕生活再糟糕，但只要还活着，似乎一切都没那么差劲。
可是不行。死已经是既定事实，不会改变，也不曾通融。你所做的一切都没有意义，所想的全部都将归为虚无。

还值得努力吗？还能够寄托吗？

中学时代读【挪】，对木月的死懵懂不解，只对那句话记忆犹新：死并非生的对立面，而作为生的一部分永存。

死亡是生之伟大的证明。它客观公正，不曾放过任何一人，你我都终将面对；也不一视同仁，有人幼年夭折有人寿终正寝。它的到来你只能接受，反抗最多只是拖延时间。炽热的生之火焰迟早燃灭，冷酷的死亡钟声也定会敲响。

人一生的时间，其实并没有多少，别浪费。找对的人，作对的事。

10091875.review:
Narcissu is a Kinetic Novel - essentially something like reading a novel on the computer, only with music, voicing and background music. It's also considered an 'Utsuge', which basically means it has an incredibly heartwrenching story.

Now, onto the game itself. Without spoilers, by the end of it, you will feel for characters, the music is beautiful, while the amount art is lacking, I personally find that it adds to the themes of the game.

This isn't considered an 'Utsuge' for nothing, however. Excepting those with cold hearts of stone, you will feel sad, you may likely even cry. Though, this is far from a bad thing, and it has some pretty thought provoking themes such as, without spoiling too much, the fate of those with no place in society and suicide.

It is quite short read, it only took me a few hours to complete. So if you're looking for a short, yet powerful read, and aren't afraid to shed some manly(or womanly) tears, then by all means try this out. I can all but guarantee you will not regret it.

With just around 2 hours put into it...I feel like I've just barely scratched the surface of Narcissu...

I didn't really know what to expect going into this at all, despite the many reviews that are about this.  I admit it took a little bit to get into the story...and I'm really just on the first episode, or really what feels like an introduction.  But maybe 10-15 min I just got hooked and couldn't stop reading.  Looking at some of the other people and the time with this title I feel like I have a long way to go...and frankly, I'm excited.

The story telling felt awkward at first but when I realized it was like a manga but needing to visualize the majority myself (there are plenty of story card images to help along the way)...I just fell straight into the story and got hooked.

The imagery mentioned above is simple and at times hazy...which I feel like is a connection to the characters themselves.

And the music...probably one of my favorites parts of this thus far.  The music is probably the biggest part of the whole package to me and just the ride I end up taking sinking myself into the depths the music can take me while the characters figure out what they really want of the lives they have...

I really can't wait to get into it more, but I feel like I need to keep watch over myself else I'll lose the time and put myself into a bad situation, especially if I get into more of it late at night. lol...

As I've mentioned before, I'm just on Narcissu 1st right now and maybe 7 or 8 chapters in.  I have no idea how long 1st is...nor an inkling of 2nd, but I can't wait to see where they all go...

If 2nd is actually a prequel and 1st is the main story like one review says...maybe I should have started that way, but I think I'll finish 1st since I've just dove into that anyways.

10072883.review:
Another brilliant Visual Novel with touching, well written story. Narcissu shows that even text can convey the deepest of the emotion.

To play the 'game', you need to sit back, relax, click thru the dialogues slowly and enjoy it. Just don't forget to occassionally save so you won't bang your head against the wall if your machine magically crashes and you need to restart the story all over again.

Replayability is zero. Once you finish once, that's all you need to do. Except if you want to recall the story later.

As an Early Access, Narcissu is pretty much done and polished - except for blank so-called Achievements - and most importantly it's completely translated into English. I'm surprised they didn't charge a dime for this on Steam.

The only purchasable DLC here is OSTs. While I don't own the DLC myself, it's been said that the quality of the OSTs are FLAC, pretty much what we expect nowadays (who likes lossy MP3s now?). Even so, I can vet for the quality of the OSTs in-game, it's very memorable and deep, perfectly blend into the story and I can fully recommend this set for your listening pleasure.

All in all, it's a free stuff with great presentation and story that you can finish in one sitting (at least for each part). Well worth your time. 10/10.

The voice-over is not complete but when present adds a unique connection to an already emotion packed dialogue. It is, however, the soft keening of the somber soundtrack that accompanies each backdrop that will make this story one to remember.

10024519.review:
I actually never heard of this Visual novel before i saw it on steam; I saw it on Greenlight, and I voted for it (mainly because I am a HUGE visual novel fan; even to the point of adding Katawa Shoujo to my non-steam steam games). I saw it finally was released and decided to download it immediately. I then sat down and beat the 1st 'side'; and decided to write my review (also apologies if it is vague, I wanted to avoid spoilers, and this is my first in depth review I wrote). 

This visual novel is quite amazing in my opinion; it really brought emotion out of me, something most movies, games, and books cannot do (although there have been one or two games and books, and a handful of movies).

There aren't too many images used, but what images are used are amazing looking, and are very beautiful. The dialog is very descriptive, and it is translated amazingly. 

The music score/soundtrack to this game is just as amazing as the rest of this visual novel; it fits in perfectly, and both sets and amplifies the mood, making the scenes much more powerful. (The soundtrack is available for purchase, and i recomend picking it up if you have the money)

The impact this game left on me is strong, I even cried at the end [I know; I’m a dork ha-ha] because of its depressing... but strangely satisfying and even somewhat happy ending (I know this seems like a contradicting statement; but it will make sense when you beat it).  

I whole-heartedly recommend this to anyone who enjoys visual novels, great stories, or emotionally charged entertainment; best of all is that this amazing experience is free. I give narcissu a 10/10!!

Narcissu 1st & 2nd is a Japanese visual novel developed by stage-nana and written originally in Japanese by Tomo Kataoka. This VN tells the story about the residence of 7th floor Setsumi Sakura and her experience during the last moment of her life.

10012590.review:
Like so many VN's, Narcissu delivers what no other game medium is capable of. Pure, positive, negative, happy and sad feelings. You read, you imagine you will feel.

I don't want to tell anything about the stories, but it's a very, very good experience and it gives you a certain understanding why some terminal patients decide to do certain things. it makes you understand, not always accept, but understand that not all people are born to live a long life and that the length of ones life doesn't really guarantee a good quality. Sometimes it's better to end things prematuraly. And Narcissu gives you insight in those situations and some of the feelings that come with it.

10012148.review:
[b]Ich trenne die Spiele untereinander ab. Der zweite Teil folgt weiter unten.[/b]

[u]Narcissu[/u]

Narcissu ist ein Spiel, welches mehr eine Geschichte ist als ein Spiel. Die Handlung behandelt ein ernstes Thema: Eine tödliche Krankheit. Ein Spiel, welches die Geschichte zwei todkranken Personen erzählt.

Pro
- Rührende Story
- Mitfühlen der Charaktere
- Leichte Bedienung
- Schöne Bilder(An den Zeichenstyle muss man sich jedoch erst gewöhnen)
- Fabelhafte Musik

Contra
- Auf Englisch(Allerdings gibt es eine Deutsche Version im Netz)
- Kurze Spieldauer

Fazit:
Ein wirklich tolles Spiel mit einer wundervollen Geschichte. Mehr als nur empfehlenswert!

Punkte
- Story 8,7/10
- Charaktere 7,0/10
- Grafik 7,5/10
- Gameplay 7,0/10
- Musik 9,5/10

Ergebnis: 7,94/10



[u]Narcissu Side 2nd[/u]

Narcissu Side 2nd spielt in der Vergangenheit und die Geschichte der weiblichen Protagonistin wird erzählt.

Pro
- Rührende Story
- Mitfühlen der Charaktere
- Leichte Bedienung
- Schöne Bilder(An den Zeichenstyle muss man sich jedoch erst gewöhnen)
- Fabelhafte Musik

Contra
- Bis jetzt nur auf Englisch
- Kurze Spieldauer

Fazit:
Ein wirklich tolles Spiel mit einer wundervollen Geschichte. Mehr als nur empfehlenswert!

Punkte
- Story 8,7/10
- Charaktere 7,2/10
- Grafik 7,5/10
- Gameplay 7,0/10
- Musik 9,5/10

Ergebnis: 7,98/10


[u]Gesamte Bewertung[/u]

Narcissu und Narcissu Side 2nd ist eine wunderbare Spielserie. Wer diese Geschichte an sich vorbei rauschen lässt, dem entgeht etwas. Das Thema ist zwar nicht gerade leicht zu verkraften, aber trotzdem beinhaltet die Narcissu-Serie wundervolle Bilder und eine spannende und zugleich rührende Geschichte.

Folgender Text enthält Spoiler

[spoiler]Der erste Teil fand ich sehr gut. Einige Szenen kommen total unerwartet und das macht das Spiel/die Geschichte umso besser. Setsumi ist anfangs noch das mysteriöse und seltsame Mädchen. Doch im Laufe der Geschichte zeigt sie ihre wahre Persönlichkeit. Im Gegensatz zu ihr kann man sich in den männlichen Protagonisten besser hineinversetzen. Anfangs ist Setsumi sehr schwer zu durchschauen, da sie erst spät ihr wahres Ich zeigt. Doch bei dem männ. Protagonist erhält man etwas Verständnis. Er erfährt, dass er an Lungenkrebs erkrankt ist und sterben wird. Sein gesamtes vorheriges Leben verändert sich von jetzt auf eben. Alles ist Neu und anders. Deswegen kann man sich in ihn besser hineinversetzen.
Der zweite Teil ist meiner Meinung nach sehr gelungen und sogar noch besser als der Erste. Es wird Setsumis Vergangenheit erzählt. Aber gleichzeitig auch neue Charakter eingefügt. Anfangs hat man es noch schwer mit zu kommen, aber nach der Zeit versteht man alles. Der zweite Teil hat mich mehr zu Tränen geführt als der Erste. Wahrscheinlich wegen dem Kind, der Schwester und Yuka.[/spoiler]

Punkte:
- Story 9,0/10
- Charaktere 7,2/10
- Grafik 7,5/10
- Gameplay 7,0/10
- Musik 9,5/10

Ergebnis: 8,04/10

10011713.review:
Antes de comenzar: Narcissu no es un juego, es una Novela Visual (o ni eso, ya que tienes 0 control en la historia. De todas maneras soy bastante ignorante acerca de VNs así que corrijanme si me equivoco.) No tiene nada de jugabilidad, ya que se centra 95%, o por ahí, en la historia.

Narcissu cuenta una historia de unos jóvenes que esperan a la muerte en el llamado "7mo Piso" (7th floor) a causa de una enfermedad incurable. La historia, la cual se va contando acompañada con diapositivas y música de fondo añadiendo peso a la historia, se centra en esta chica de 22 años, llamada Setsumi, quien a pesar de no tener ningún objetivo en la vida, no quiere morir ni en su casa, ni en el 7mo piso. Narcissu realmente te toca el corazón, sobretodo al final cuando [spoiler]Setsumi logra posar en un traje de baño, justo como las chicas que veía en las revistas que solía leer en sus momentos de aburrimiento[/spoiler].

Personalmente he jugado... Bueno, leído, Narcissu 1st, aún no he tocado la 2da parte. Pero aún así, si quieren una buena historia, les recomiendo esta. Narcissu está gratis en Steam, así que no pierdes nada.

10002188.review:
One of the few Visual Novels currently on Steam,  Narcissu is an expirience unlike one I have ever had before.  It isn't really a game, and in fact can't really even be considered a Visual Novel in the broad sense of the term.  It literally is a novel; one with pictures, music and partial narration.  This is a sad, soulful piece of art that also tends to branch away from traditional VN expirirences by not having a palphable romantic streak or a hard, action based storyline. Although I am only at chapter 3 in 1st, I am completely enthralled and did start crying at some of the more eloquently worded scenes of reflection.  Again, although I have barely touched the surface I have no doubt that for all the more abstract and open-minded gamers out there who can accept a touching linear click-and-read this is a must.

11/10

10000639.review:
ALL ABOARD THE FEELS TRAIN!!
Without further ado let's start: 

Story - You ''play'' an unnamed 20 year old man, suffering from an terminal illness called lung carcinoma who has been hospitalized and will die because of that illness, they place him in a wing called 7F where he meets a  young woman named Setsumi, 22 years of age. she has a body physique like a child and has a quiet personality. The story properly begins when the protagonists father visits his son in the hospital and leaves his car keys on a table, protagonist takes them and invites Setsumi to go along with him. The two escape the hospital and begin a roadtrip with seemingly no end goal.

Gameplay - The game is a visual novel with little to no interaction if you have autoscroll on the text, so it isn't a ''game'' excactly.

Voice acting and presentation - The ''game'' has very little of the characters and is compromised of a textwindow and a narrow movielike image, the voiceacting is completely optional but i recommend turning it on with autoplay enabled so you don't accidentally skip any speech.

Overall the visual novel is touching and has a very sad undertone driven by the fate of the main characters (incurable illness) so they both know they will die soon or sooner and the novel leaves a bittersweet taste of tears afterwards so i would conclude this with a rating for anyone who loves sad stories of visual novels definetly a 8/10 (would feel again) but for any other person do not expect too much.

9989941.review:
Allow me to introduce you to Narcissu, produced by Stage Nana. There are three visual novels (two being free to play): the Narcissu (the original), Narcissu Side 2nd, and Narcissu 3rd – Die Dritte Welt. (And yes, the story does reference narcissus (daffodils)). I read through the first two and found it very thought-provoking. I will give you a brief summary of the games without giving any spoilers (unless I have no other info), and then I will give you my detailed reviews.

Narcissu:

The story revolves around a character named Yuu Atou, a college-age student (about 21), and a reclusive girl named Setsumi Sakura (age 22). The story is told from the first-person perspective of Atou. The two of them are both sick to the point where they are going to die (there is no known cure for their diseases), and thus they have been confined to the 7th floor of a Catholic hospital, the hospice, where they sit around doing nothing exciting. The boy insists they take off, and opportunity falls in his lap.

Narcissu Side 2nd:

Setsumi returns, but this time, the story is chronologically-earlier than the original. A former-Catholic girl named Himeko, who for a time volunteered at a hospital, ends up meeting Setsumi. Like the first visual novel, the story carries on with the two gallivanting off to various distant places in spite of sickness.

Story:

I played through the original Narcissus first. I’m glad I read it that way – Side 2nd is better in both story and presentation. The first novel is long, and by that I don’t mean text-wise (it’s only four chapters) – I mean it’s dragged out. Not much is really going on. The writer keeps things realistic in that there is no secret source of healing or some new medical technology the characters must find to save themselves. There appears to be no hope period. There isn’t anything to do, hence the characters are seeking something. That’s the ultimate goal – to just get it all over with. But even that goal isn’t existent, or rather, obvious, until the very end. In as much as it lacked direction (Don’t misunderstand me: I appreciated the realism), the little things added up. For instance, how does Setsumi know so much about vehicles (and contrary to other bloggers, it’s not because she’s fascinated with cars)? Why does she have so much money saved up? Why does she want to visit the beach? Questions like these are all answered in Side 2nd. Spoiler: We learn that all of these things are simply ideas inherited from Himeko. Hence, the first story laid the groundwork for the second, chronologically-earlier story.

The story of the second novel is different from the first in a few respects. First, the story isn’t solely centered on Setsumi all the time. It was nice actually being able to see things from Himeko’s point of view concerning her own life. The time given to Himeko as well as her relevance in the story makes the story seem more like it was written about two people, each with their own separate story and each just as significant. Both are the central protagonists, both have their own story, and yet both interact with each other on a very frequent basis. The plot of the second novel develops better than the first: it actually has a direction. Himeko has a list of things that she wants to accomplish, and the mystery as to what those are adds some intrigue to her activities. The presentation of Himeko’s background also adds some variance to the story and is important, given that it shows her lack of faith and helps explain why she no longer refers to herself as Catholic (though she continues to believe in God). Concerning Setsumi, her silent nature is highlighted. Plus, she isn’t portrayed as the reclusive, paranoid character we get in the first novel. Rather, she is simply quiet and polite. Her politeness is not habit, but it isn’t accompanied by the normal cheer typically associated with politeness. Another aspect is that, as Himeko points out, it is hypocritical (note the fries).

Completing both stories in the Side 2nd (Narcissu 1st & 2nd) program reveals tan epilogue and full credits. Rightly so – you wouldn’t understand the epilogue unless you had read both. It was… short, and somewhat rewarding. I wish they would have finished the Himeko story (even though it was implied), but I guess it’s less emotionally straining leaving the ending like this. Note that since the epilogue was created after both stories were made, they didn’t make the same mistake of assuming that walking out with a smile is somehow happy in light of inevitable end.

I can’t emphasize enough how much I appreciated the objectivity in both stories (original and Side 2nd). Let me explain: In the end, I don’t feel a bias towards or against anyone – they are as they are and they believe what they believe. The characters, while I didn’t think of them as real, call for sympathy given their circumstances. They didn’t do anything beyond common human responses. While I don’t agree with Himeko and eventually Setsumi did, I do understand realize that many people see things way and don’t have reason to believe otherwise. Hence, within their own frame of mind, they were justified in doing what they did. As for Yuu Atou, he acted out of the desperateness of his situation. I wasn’t in favor of him escaping from the consequences of his actions, but neither did I condemn him. I was disappointed that he stole things, but it was all in the passing of the moment. Being on the run isn’t justification for acting like a fool, but it is realistic to act like a fool when on the run.

Meh:

As an oddity, Yuu Atou never actually introduces himself. Furthermore, none of the characters really indicate their age. The hints at age occur when Chihiro mentions she went to college and she addresses Himeko as being older. An occasional picture of a character might be shown, but anime-style characters have that funny way of making it difficult to tell what age they are. The images we see of Setsumi seem to indicate she is very young in both the original and Side 2nd novels. She is in the latter since it’s chronologically earlier. However, it seems to me that the story could just as easily have been told if she had hardly aged.

A note should be made about the medical field. The author didn’t do as good a job as he could have about making the world of the hospice realistic. Instead, his primary concern was with story, so the truth about hospitals was neglected to a considerable extent. Care and life in the hospices isn’t as bad as the author made it out to be.

Overall:

Frankly, I rather enjoyed the read. It was very thought-provoking. It was a long-drawn out experience, and it didn’t help that I read it during the only hours I had time each day: between midnight and four in the morning. Take my advice and get some sleep, but if you happen to have a slot for time open between 10 and midnight, let me just say, the cinematic and emotional aura of stories like this is always enhanced at night. Trust me on that.
You should definitely give it a try.

9984798.review:
So, I know I'm not that deep into the story, but there are a few things I'd like to state from the time I've spent (And please, if you're already doing these things, then disregard this completely).

-First off, I like the story. It's a rather sad tale that has a nice setup and a lot of interesting perspective from our protagonist. Just wanted to let you know that.
-However (and I'm assuming this is part of the early access) there are so few pictures or discussions in this visual novel. I'd like to feel the family strain to smile at the protagonist, and have the discussion with the girl whose hair goes to her hips. So much of the story right now just has a blank screen or the background (which is very beautiful, I might add), but the characters need to be there.
-Finally, the story so far is doing a lot of "tell, don't show" with what the protagonist sees, like with the friends playing with her and not coming around as often, or the family around her being as friendly as possible. Simply put, we're told all these things are happening, but I think it would really help to drive the point if we had even a small conversation with some kids when the protagonist is sick, or talking with the family and seeing that smile, wondering why it's so abnormal. This doesn't have to be like adding in minigames and moving around, but just a few slides where the protagonist and characters are having these moments.

All in all, I really can't wait until it's finished. I'm nervous of going further to spoil the story when the whole thing comes out, but I just might have to keep playing! Great work so far!

9973150.review: Narcissu isn't what most people think of when they think of a video game. But that is because this is a visual novel. This game has received negative comments claiming it's all script and artwork with no real play. They are correct. But they failed to realize, is that Narcissu is a visual novel and that script and artwork is all a visual novel is. They chose to judge the game on what it's not instead of what it is. Me on the other hand, I highly enjoyed this game. The artwork is detailed and beutiful, the story is depressing but well done, and the setup for the game is great. As the description says, this is about a girl and a boy both dying of desease. Wanting to escape from the fate laid out for them. They knew they would die. They knew that there was nothing they could do. But they leave 7f. I highly enjoyed this game. I cried on several occasions. So prepare for feels if you play. I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys storyline or visual novels. 10/10

9967617.review:
Narcissu 1st & 2nd conta uma história muito intensa sobre os "habitantes" do 7º andar.
Na primeira história, você está na visão de um menino, que no caso seria "você" e como ele encontra uma garota chamada Setsumi, paciente do 7º andar.
"Habitantes" do 7º andar são pessoas que já estão na fase terminal de uma doença, onde não há cura e nem esperança para eles, assim como dizem os personagens "estamos esperando para morrer".
Já na segunda história, Narcissu 2nd é dividido na visão de uma outra garota chamada Himeko e a própria Setsumi. Claro que a maior parte você vê pela visão da Setsumi, quando ela não era uma paciente do 7ºandar.
E então ela conhece Himeko já moradora do 7º andar.
Narcissu 1st é alguns anos depois de Narcissu 2nd.

9963341.review: Narcissu 1 et 2 ne sont pas des jeux à proprement parler : ce sont ce qu'on appelle des "Visuals Novels", comprendre par là des histoires imagées. En effet, tout ce que vous aurez à faire ici sera de lire et de cliquer pour faire défiler les lignes de dialogues. De temps en temps, des images (graphiquement et artistiquement très belles) viendront ponctuer les scénarii afin d'accroitre l'immersion.  A ce propos, les histoires sont vraiment très bien écrites ; on les suit sans en décrocher. Par ailleurs, elles ne sont disponibles qu'en anglais : rassurez-vous, le niveau requis n'est pas incroyablement élevé (un niveau lycée suffit largement). En bref, je recommande très fortement de télécharger ces magnifiques histoires pour passer un très bon moment, loin des barbaries des jeux plus classiques.

9959959.review:
没想到水仙登入 steam了！点赞！ 
当初阅读了相关的小说之后并玩了这部游戏
这是一部平淡而又悲伤的故事。初读时觉得生命微弱而渺小。当简单的日常渐行渐远时，死亡越来越近时，我一直感受到了悲哀与绝望。当濑津美走向生命的尽头时，有一种深深的绝望，那种绝望阻隔了任何希望。
当然，后来我通了两次游戏之后觉得水仙绝对不是一个消极的故事。我看到濑津美最后所展露出来的笑容时，我想她已经实现了自己的愿望了吧。生命到了最后一刻也要绽放出光彩，她在生命的最后一刻，在淡路岛的海边向世人展示出最后的笑容，也许这也是她的愿望吧。虽然路上的过程非常艰难，但是只要在绝望中有一丝希望，有时付诸生命也在所不惜。当你比其它人早一步离开的时候……要为还活着的人留下一抹笑靥……」，「在翡翠色的大海前… 她会兴奋地，喜悦地，宛如偶像明星一般地对着我微笑…」。濑津美已经达成了她的愿望。
对于喜欢这游戏的朋友来说，买这dlc也是对这游戏登入steam的最大的支持

9959266.review: 윈도우8.1과 호환성이 좋지 않지만, 실행하는 것은 문제가 없었습니다. 이 게임의 OST는 아름답고 슬펐습니다. 이 게임이 상징하는 분위기와 더불어 이 게임이 보여주는 모든 것을 그려내는 것 같았습니다. 그건 감정선을 두드릴 정도로 놀라울 만큼 짜릿한 경험을 선사합니다. 인간에게 죽음은 결코 달갑지 않은 소재입니다. 등장인물들은, 심지어 주인공 조차도 죽음에 얽힌 인물들 뿐입니다. 이어 플레이어는 그들과의 은유적인 대사에서 죽음의 슬프고 그윽한 낭만을 보게 됩니다. 지도를 좋아하고 여행을 좋아하는 소녀도, 플란더스의 개를 아는 그녀도 모두 자신의 죽음을 알고 있습니다. 이 이야기는 플란더스의 개입니다. 슬픔만 가득한 이 이야기 속에서, 그것이 달콤하지 않더라도 아름답지 않더라도 단맛이 나는 희망을 그려내는 좋은 작품입니다.

9959207.review:
I've just finished the first story, and let me just say... wow. I don't even know what to type right now; it's been a long time since I've been this depressed. The story is about a male protagonist (who remains anonymous, probably for immersive purposes), and a quiet woman who's a few years older than him. Both have been denied their future. Not wanting to have their final moments in a hopsital or at home, the two run away. Initially with no goal in mind, the two travel aimlessly before deciding to finally set their sights on the narcissus fields in Awaji Island.

Do I recommend this game? Yes, but be prepared to feel sad. I really took a feels trip with this visual novel. Also the music is great- at least a x3 feels multiplier. It moved me and changed the way that I looke at things. Anyway, the less info you know about the game, the better experience you'll have with it- that's my opinion. Consider taking a few hours out of your day to experience this beautiful, yet sad piece crafted by Tomo Kataka.

Note- Give it a go even if you don't like the 'anime' style of it. You will only see the characters a few times- most of it will be just settings; you can also chose to have it unvoiced. Pressing 'a' will turn on auto progress if you're tired of clicking.

Will update after finishing the second story. For now, I'm sorta scared to progress.

9957448.review: Quite possibly the most depressing thing ever. Very bitter sweet, with very small hints of romance. I actually cried during this 'game'. can't wait for 3rd

9957205.review:
Few novels of any sort are dedicated to chronic or terminal illness, especially when they afflict the young.  I'm as close to an expert as one can be on this subject and still be living.  I survived a nearly fatal heart issue at age 18 and had two open heart surgeries.  I also volunteered in the child life department (duties very similar to the "helper" in this story -- basically being a supportive friend) for several years at a children's hospital on the acute care floor, the hem/onc floor and the NICU.

That said, I was really intrigued by this and hoping to find something that spoke to the experiences I have shared with children who I have worked with who are terminally ill and the friends I have made in support groups who have struggled with giant chest scars in their teens, coping with confronting death while your college friends are out partying, learning to change your IV bags while your bff is talking about her favorite clothes, and generally losing your supposed best years of your life.

I was ideally hoping for something I could pass on to my friends who have dealt with these same issues or my family who truly cannot fathom what that kind of life experience does to an 18-23 year old.  Unfortunately, I can't say that this really deals with many of the issues we face.  I believe that there are some really important points it manages to pick up on briefly that healthy individuals may not have ever considered: the families that abandon children in hospitals because it's too much to bear, the isolation of the young in a landscape of the dying elderly, the alienation one feels from her own body -- particularly because of scarring or the presentation of what is considered acceptable by the fashion industry.  

However, I did think this could have used some editing and likely some research into specific illnesses as well.  Portraying nebulous illnesses, sternotomy scars and "medications" didn't really impact me when that kind of stuff becomes your daily bag in reality.  I also thought some of the character switches were clumsy at times, though the pay-offs at times when things came full circle was cute.  All in all, though, I was left feeling like this did not ring true to the experiences I knew of we young folk trapped in hospitals -- though it was a valiant attempt and some people might enjoy it.  I wouldn't recommend it to my friends or families to learn more about our experiences, and I wouldn't recommend it to my peers as an introspective dip into our pasts.

I think my largest problem was the complete absence of the illness, its accoutrements and its physical impacts from these characters despite their being apparently near death.  I get that this isn't a documentary, but truly, being half machine, rooted semi-permanently to various tubes, plugs and massive IVs, and being sliced and diced is such a huge part of what one has to process and your identity while your best friends are just like, "Man.  Essays suck."  The fact that the characters only deal with half of dying is a hard thing for me to let go of, especially when the characters just generally seem to be withering away from a general 19th c malaise.

Barely recommended as a fair attempt to portray a complex subject on which the authors did not have a clear grasp.  Glad someone tackled it, however.  6/10.

O jogo Narcissu 1st e 2nd é triste e bonito, tem que ter paciência para jogar, ou melhor, ler...
É Visual Novel ta Gratis na steam, Narcissu 1st conta a história de um rapaz  (o protagonista ) doente terminal que se encontra no 7º andar de um hospital. 9949226.review:
痛苦产生于意志，终究也要由意志来解决。人生的究竟，宇宙的究竟。“生活”、“苦痛”、“解脱”，这是全部人生的三要素，除此之外，没有人生，也没有世界。

生命渐渐陷入沉默与黑暗，在黑暗中，现实得以被点亮。在沉默中，外界的声音逐渐渗入空气。

我曾经相信生命有一种动力，驱使着我。它是过去与未来的源泉，但这种动力却是最让人害怕的，无穷的追逐，却发现自己在原地踏步。
生命的动力——“希望”，慢慢的消逝与幻灭，显示出“绝望”与“虚无”的真实存在和绝对权威。我曾听过这样一句话：“这个世上唯有无是最完美的,因为存在必将残缺消逝。”就像我的生命吗？它也在慢慢的残缺，消逝。

我飘渺的身躯，仿佛深陷于沼泽之中，慢慢衰弱，慢慢沉溺，渐渐枯萎。在病房内，那样的生活，是有无数限制的生活，与一只鸟，活在笼子里，是一样的。选择那样活下去，还是选择放弃，是各人的权利。大部分人，都是在病房里任人摆布的，我却希望能自由的死去。即使与孤独为伴，孤独的死去，也是孤独的自由。

疑惑，懊悔，无奈！哪里有救赎？我们的思想，经验，文化，灵感，想象力，和感性，都不能逃离生命的局限。我害怕死亡，但我更害怕无法避免死亡的人生。

真实的生命，在虚拟的游戏中，在影像，音乐和文字里。我就像无家可归的人，暴露在众人的目光中，疑惑，嘲讽，排斥，共鸣，怜悯，理解。我向任何人诉说自己的遭遇，就像一种记忆，一个影像接着一个影像，完整的记录直到结束，还有不间断的声音和幻想。这也是一个真实的世界，我拥有生命，我活在影像，音乐和文字里。死又何妨？

9949201.review:
A mature and painfully saddening tale that will leave you engrossed in your feelings aftering completing it, Narcissu was a great find for me reccomended by a friend. Iv'e only just read the first one and I can say as a visual novel fan I fell in love with this story. Griping, paced well and told with some good voice acting the musical scores really helped set the tone for this story. From the start it captivates you, bringing you along for the feels train. If I had to rate this out of a 10 I'd give it a 8; however, I think it may have been better as just a novel albeit myself enjoying the voice of Setsuna and the wonderful music. For a visual novel it lacked the art  expected of it and at times left me wanting more, as an example where you'd expect a stunning image of Setsuna giving her "bashful sour expression" you often weren't rewarded it. Yet, this does not take away from the beauty of this VN, nor should it deter you. If you are a fan of this type of genre, enjoy reading or simply want to play something to pass time its well it. With a fantasitcly saddening story, moving musical selection and spot on voice acting Its a gem in the visual novel bin.

(PLACE HOLDER FOR PART 2)

9948851.review:
Narcissus（纳西斯）是希腊神话里的一位美少年，他拒绝了其他女神的追求。因为纳西斯爱恋自己在水中的倒影，最后他为了拥抱自己的形象而溺水身亡。就在他死后的湖边，生出了一丛紫蕊白瓣的花，后来人们称为水仙花。「水仙花」的英文正是narcissus，而「自恋」的英文narcissism也是源于这个希腊神话。
  其实如果我们把全文通篇阅读之后，恐怕很少人会想明白剧本作家为何会取一个这么奇怪的名字。Narcissus在西方更多是“孤芳自赏者”、“自我陶醉者”的代名词。
  于是仔细想来，作者似乎并不是完全是一个孤芳自赏的家伙。就算是依靠着这篇剧本，ta也并不是刻意在表现出一种高高在上的情感。而本身这部作品也不过是作者的一面镜子，或者可以说是纳西斯窥视自己美貌的河水，而ta也只是一个孤芳自怜的人罢了，谈不上能欣赏什么。
  因为这个世界本身就没有什么值得欣赏的。还记得通篇上来那惊人的自杀数字吗？日本是全世界自杀率最高的国家之一，我们对于作者现实的生活背景，无从知晓。或许ta其实正是文章中自杀的女孩的翻版，亦或是那个遭到排斥抛弃的少年，或者或者ta只是另一个第三者，仅仅是在面无表情诉说着一个事实。
  一个只有身患重病的人所能感受到的情感，那种遭受别人抛弃的苦涩，和行将远去的宿命。
  说不上来的滋味。确实一开始当自己的残酷命运被知晓的时候，周遭的人当然感到惋惜和惊愕，开始的时候或许会很同情你，但是生活依旧得继续，很快你就会被抛弃，再也得不到别人丝毫的怜悯。
  这种情感最后甚至会演化成嫌弃和厌恶。
  作者自然是明白这种感情的，所以ta必然不会写一个没有意义的文章，更不会起一个莫名其妙的题目。
  没有人想死，更没有人愿意被人抛弃。只不过联想起开篇那么巨大的数字，突然令人觉得作者笔下的一个女孩的死也不过尔尔。 
  表面上看起来日本资源人均水平还说得过去，但是想想其国土面积大多数是山地，实际上日本的人口密度是很恐怖的。遭到大众排斥的对象就很容易被孤立，生存不下去。
  所以日本的文化中比中国更加随大流和虚伪。因为不随大流就会被孤立，最后就跟作者笔下那个少年差不了太多。
  现实中的苦闷得不到诉说，再加上生活的压力之大，所以日本流行动漫和游戏，因为可以暂时忘却苦闷的现实。
  其实也许作者也不知道自己到底想表达什么，但是ta编织了这么一个故事。一个虚拟的但是却无比现实的故事，一个悲伤的但是又戛然而止的故事。  
  但是就是这样一种令人似懂非懂，结局停止在恰到好处的地方的故事。
  使得我们对这个故事不需要再去追寻下去，也无需再次观赏一次。
  因为没有必要，这个是作者的水仙，作者看清自己的河水和镜子。
  恰如其分也是每位读者的镜子，它并不能解决现实中的这些问题，但是它教会我们看清自己。
  面对现实我们应该做些什么，面对现实我们实际上是处在一个什么样的位置和次元？
  是河岸上的真实现实的我？
  还是那个河水里倒影着令人无比着迷的虚拟世界里的“我”？
  当我们面临这样一个问题去抉择的时候，实际上我们不需要半点犹豫。

9946922.review:
【死中窥生。】（有剧透慎读）



水仙。无选项无操作的视觉小说，娓娓道来两个身罹绝症的人最后那段时光，以及最终如何面对死亡。平淡叙事，没有大起大落，但能感受到那种生的气息被一点点抽离，死亡越走越近的无力感和绝望。
有人选择完成心愿后平静面对，有人逃离医院以自己的方式结束。

想如果是自己该如何。

肉体饱经折磨，简单不过的日常却已渐行渐远，自己与亲人的希望幻想被一次次打击，最终万念俱灰，只剩下一个代表结束的倒计时。
万千留恋不舍，终于懂得哪怕生活再糟糕，但只要还活着，似乎一切都没那么差劲。
可是不行。死已经是既定事实，不会改变，也不曾通融。你所做的一切都没有意义，所想的全部都将归为虚无。

还值得努力吗。

中学时代读【挪】，对木月的死懵懂不解，只对那句话记忆犹新：死并非生的对立面，而作为生的一部分永存。

死亡是生之伟大的证明。它客观公正，不曾放过任何一人，你我都终将面对；也不一视同仁，有人幼年夭折有人寿终正寝。它的到来你只能接受，反抗最多只是拖延时间。炽热的生之火焰迟早燃灭，冷酷的死亡钟声也定会敲响。

人一生的时间，其实并没有多少，别浪费。找对的人，作对的事。


PS：半年过去了，现在想来，正是水仙的影响，才有了山桂在steam的登陆，和以后其他AVG游戏发行的可能性。感谢它让我在感悟了一个故事的同时，也收获了小小的事业和成就。

Narcissu is a VN that lacks the typical VN feeling of agency, the feeling of that you are making your own decisicion or dialogue choices.what I mean by lacking is that This game has none of those, oh no.This VN is literaly a VN, a Visual Novel.With no interactions and no branching storyline whatsoever, however.The game provides a strong narative that immerses you with the characters.With death as a theme and a canvas for the narative, death is a inevitable end and This VN doesnt contain any romance.Which is not this VN is about, this VN is about death and of one's experience before their demise.

I dont recommend this game for people who wants agency and romance in their VNs ,because there is none.

For a visual novel, Narcissu is pretty short, but definitely worth downloading. It offers an intruiging look at life, death, and terminal illness, with a gorgeous soundtrack and interesting characters to go along with it. My only gripe with it was the narrow screen, which may have just been an aesthetic choice on the designer's part. 

If you don't like reading, I cannot recommend this game to you, as it has you read a lot of dialogue and monologues. If you do like reading, however, and don't mind that you'll be doing nothing but clicking to advance to the next piece of dialogue, this might be a great entry point to the world of visual novels.

i don't really read visual novels such as these, Narcissu has now become one of my favourite novels.
it really makes you think and feel what each character is going through which makes you want to read more, i guess in a way it almost makes you addicted to the "Emotions" of which you feel through out  Narcissu of course aswell backed up with a great soundtrack and voices.

9940255.review:
二月我养了三株水仙。
在节后不久终于开出了第一朵如期待中、美丽的花朵。雪白的花瓣、鲜黄的副冠，“金盏银台”。
只是，当我看着那小小的、第一朵的时候，本应兴奋的心情，却急速冷却下来。
呐..三倍体的水仙、依靠球茎繁殖、不能结出种实的水仙，为什么要如此努力地开花呢？
一年仅一次，忍冬绽放的娇小花朵，对水仙自己却是没有意义的东西。
生命真是恶质的玩笑。


---------------------------------------
“你本来应该有一个姐姐或者妹妹的。”
那一天，大人的话语在耳边回荡。
那一天，仍显稚嫩的我第一次知道了我是被折断的半边羽翼，我的出生伴随着她的死亡。
那一天，仍显稚嫩的我开始自以为是地认为自己背负着两个生命的重量活着。

渐渐地，见着身边一个又一个生命的消逝，我放弃勉强自己，也放弃努力了。
因为，我不明白啊，生命的意义。
人生长不过百年。
我不知道为了什么而生，也不知道为了什么而死。
等发觉这一点时，我已经在这世上彷徨了二十年了。
---------------------------------------


她们终于满开了清香淡雅的小花。
为了防止叶片徒长，延长花期，我将她们置于温度较低的室外，每天照看。

那是三月中旬的事。
那一天，刮着风，下起了雨。
那一天，在通勤的路上，我骑着车摔倒了，右手受了伤。
那一天，回到家中的我，看到的是——

球茎在地上散落，叶片被吹折，花轴被吹折，花瓣被吹散。
明明..花期至少还能保持一周的...
都是我的错……


---------------------------------------
“明明不需要努力就可以呼吸，活下去和寻死却都需要勇气。”
好像，无论哪一种的勇气和理由我都没有呐。

贫困抑或富裕，幸福抑或不幸，满足抑或不满，抑或喜怒哀乐，甚至是爱。
无论这些我拥有还是不曾拥有，我都日复一日地“活着”，并且，不知道这么活着的意义。
所以，我为自己所做的一切，究竟有什么意义？
腾蛇乘雾，终为土灰。
似乎什么都无所谓了。
---------------------------------------


放着不管是不行的。丢掉是不行的。
尽管受了很严重的伤，但她们还活着。

我用左手握着铁锹，笨拙地铲着土。
并不是葬花。

“嘿咻...这样，你们就不用再怕风和雨了呐，安心地，睡个好觉吧。”
这个样子，尽管我也不知道她们究竟能否活得下去，姑且，为她们做好了土培休眠的准备。
我和你们都好好努力吧，在心里如此约定了。


---------------------------------------
“如果我不在了的话会有人难过”“如果我好好努力的话会有人高兴”“他们有坚定的理想和信念，他们不曾考虑过生命的意义这种死循环”
我如此安慰着自己，自以为是地认为他人对我还抱有着期待。
没办法啊..也只能再稍稍努力一下装作普通人了呐。如果别人知道我是这么消极的人类的话，会有很多困扰吧。
给别人添麻烦我还是会心塞的。
既然找不到什么意义，那么先就，随心所欲地，活着吧。
---------------------------------------


“生不知死亦不知，岁月只是如梦中。”
我将继续，在如梦的人生中，找寻着似乎永远找不到的生命的意义。
期待着，下个凛冬，与你们再见。

劇情與音樂都相當出色的電子小說。
　　Narcissu 1st當中，唯一有人像出現的角色只有女主角瀨津美一人，登場人物極簡，可以說完全圍繞著男女主角兩個人為中心進行的故事。
　　儘管故事以兩個人的互動作為展開，卻也明明白白顯示著「故事的主角並不代表著全世界」。
　　沒有奇跡、沒有魔法、沒有熱血、沒有強力祈禱就會出現的超展開。故事結束之後，世界依然繼續轉動著，主人翁的行為並沒有改變什麼社會架構還是國家命運，就只是單純的「大城市小角落」的故事。
　　整個故事始於平淡、終於平淡，而且意味雋永。

9936503.review:
Narcissu - 水仙花 、劇本 - 片岡とも （秉持著在文字上能表達的地方盡量使用更普通的插畫，以保留讀者更多的想像空間的想法）
描述了一位少女抱著「不抱任何期望，便不會有失望」的想法和一位對於「死亡還沒有實感。對於想要做的事會積極行動」的少年之間的故事。

[url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t9AikR6kDVA] Kometto Nekono Rather Than a Life of Finality  [/url]

Narcissu為日本同人社團ステージなな（Stage Nana）製作的免費同人電子小說,
在Narcissu 1st日文版剛出不久後，就在各地引起軒然大波的討論，迅速地廣泛流傳並且出現了英文版、中文版、韓文版、法文版
以及越南文版各國的翻譯。
在Comic Market出售的同名CD遊戲內容與網上下載版完全一樣，Narcissu 1st以空出的容量收錄原聲音樂，SIDE 2nd則是另附光碟收錄原聲音樂，作為紀念、收藏用，只以收回成本的低價出售。這是由於作者是以「盡可能給更多的人看到」為理念而製作 。除此之外亦在每次的Comic Market中製作各種各樣同好向的周邊，如CD Drama、小說等。

而Narcissu 意思就是水仙花, 同時也能代表希臘神話中河神和水澤女神的兒子 ─ 納西瑟斯（Narcissus）
[spoiler]但Narcissu去掉最後則是代表自殺（Suicide）[/spoiler]

納西瑟斯是個俊美的少年，但他本身自己卻不知自己的長相到底長的怎麼樣，只能由其他人的口中得知自己的長相
這是因為當納西瑟斯的父母得知納西瑟斯只要不照鏡子就能長壽的關西。
在有天他在森林中打獵時，看到了一處平滑如鏡子的湖水，他想要到那湖水撈些清涼的水來喝，
但當他把頭一探到湖上時，他卻看到了湖中有個面如冠玉的人在看著他。
這時納西瑟斯情不自禁被湖中的這位水月觀音給吸引住，他看著湖中之人，湖中之人也看著他，
當納西瑟斯不由自主的靠近水面時，湖中之人也靠近了他，使得納西瑟斯能更清楚湖中之人的面貌，是如此的丰神俊美。
納西瑟斯對著湖中之人笑了笑，湖中之人也對他笑了笑，但當他想把手伸到湖中之人臉上時，湖中之人卻模糊不見了。
納西瑟斯對任何姑娘都不動心，卻只對自己的水中倒影愛慕不已，最終在顧影自憐中抑鬱死去。化作水仙花，仍留在水邊守望著自己的倒影。

（以上簡介來源參考 - 維基百科&妖界誌 以下心得則是結合其他人的感想與敝人以主角本身的感覺）
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Narcissu 1st & 2nd是一部感動至極又令人催淚的視覺小說，
關於一個不抱任何期望的少女
和一個對死亡沒有實感的少年
這樣的走向虛無的人們的故事。
是一段燦爛的回憶，一個絕望的故事...

Narcissu可能是我讀過最動人，最讓我感觸最深的小說，
因為在故事中可沒有熱血漫畫小說那種的超展開也沒有校園戀愛劇中的那種溫馨和諧之感，有的只是淡然的面對「死亡」這事實。
並沒有對即將失去的生命呼喊、也沒有感人的生離死別、更是沒有扭轉命運的奇蹟，剩下的只有是對生命的平淡無奇跟無奈，
而我們只是靜靜的看著少年與少女主角們走完人生最後一程。

對於我們這些正常的、快樂的、美滿的、想要做什麼就做什麼的人來說、簡直就是個上天賜予的幸福，可是我們卻不感恩。
對於其餘的人而言，他們有的只是痛苦、他們有的只是悲傷、他們有的只是絕望、他們有的只是死亡、他們有的只是無奈的接受了這事實

當他們在無奈的接受了這個世界，而我們卻是在批判這個世界。
當他們在羨慕正常人的人生的時候，而我們卻是在抗議自己的人生。
當他們在思考人生還有什麼價值的時候，而我們卻是在想像自己的人生將來會怎麼樣。
只有當我們失去我們原本的人生的時候，才會去思考以前的人生是如此的美好、如此的美滿。

Narcissu 水仙花　此小說作品我給予的評分為（11/10）

+Free 免費下載（基本上就算這部作品需要錢，我也會把這部作品給買下來。）
+很富有電影感
+動人的背景音樂
+了不起的小說劇本
+全故事以平淡風格來闡述
+闡述了瀕臨死亡的人們的故事
+使用更普通的插畫以保留讀者更多的想像空間
+作者本人不對劇本的意思另外加以解釋，讓讀者均有其不同的揣測

I remember I had this on the GP2X handheld back in 2005, except I only had the 1st story.

I'll be damned if I lie and say this didn't have me cryin' my a** off back then.
One of the best heartwarming stories in a visual novel out there.

The Steam version includes 2 stories. Narcissu which was originally released in 2005 and Narcissu: Side 2nd which was released in 2007. Unfortunately, Narcissu 3rd - Die Dritte Welt was released in 2009 only for PSP.

This is one of the best visual novels on Steam. You should definitely check it out.

9931834.review:
Narcissu 1st & 2nd is a Japanese visual novel developed by stage-nana and written originally in Japanese by Tomo Kataoka. This VN tells the story about the residence of [i]7th floor[/i] Setsumi Sakura and her experience during the last moment of her life.

This game includes both the Narcissu 1st & Narcissu 2nd. 2nd being the prequel and 1st is the main story of Setsumi. 
The 2nd tells the story of Himeko Sunohara as her life take a 180 degree turn when she was diagnosed with a diseased that can't be cured, thus she's moved to the 7th floor. Himeko used to work as helper in 7th floor so she kinda used to the situation, but then it all changes when she met Setsumi.

Narcissu 1st set appx. 6-7 years after 2nd. The story is focused on the anonymous Protagonist (just think of him as us) who is terminally ill & Setsumi as both of them realizes their feeling of not wanting to die in the hospital or at home with their respective families. The two of them begin a long journey accross Japan until they find that place...
[b] NARCISSU [/b]

I have completed the game 2 years ago and when I found this game on Steam Greenlight, I immediately vote it up as I think this [u] COULD BE[/u] first step of introducing the Visual Novel medium to the West. Currently the game is in Early Access but don't let that bother you because the story itself is completed & translated. I'm also part of the Closed Beta tester and I could say that Sekai Project did a good job of making the game engine compatible with Steamwork.

Definitely a must have if you are an avid VN player or you are interested in this medium, even after 2 years of finishing this, I still get [i] dem feels [/i] moment :') a Masterpiece indeed!
